  228. Unlike some previous reviewers comparing the two shavers, I haven't experienced hair-pulling or face-cutting problems with the Norelco, but the machine's quiet, unlabored operation frequently caused me to wonder if it was even running. More importantly, it made shaving around a beard too much of a \\"guessing game.\\" Especially if you try to maintain a consistent, even line between beard and skin at the neck, the Norelco leads to frustration--the line is constantly moving lower while becoming increasingly irregular.<br /><br />Put simply, this Remington is the one to get if your face is of a hirsute nature. (Braun once won my allegiance--until I added up the cost of continually replacing those delicate, ripped foils). The Remington MS2-390 is not only quite rugged but ergonomic, inexpensive, and darned effective. As for the \\"noise\\" that many complain about, I've come to regard it as an all-business wake-up call, a high-pitched buzz of excitement confirming that the day's first task is under way--not to mention well in hand.<br /><br />To extend the metaphor, the Norelco is a cumbersome, bloated bomber from the German Luftewaffe whereas the Remington is a British RAF Spitfire which, in the hands of a skilled pilot, can fly circles around any of the balky Teutonic Titans. Or, if you prefer, the Norelco is the feminine passive Grail; the Remington the male active Lance. Norelco purrs; Remington rocks.
  229. I'm 50 years old and have used this shaver for about 1-month now. I had to bury my 15-year old faithful 3-head rotary Norelco. I am typically NOT an every morning shaver; week days most times, but I seldom shave on the weekends. I usually don't worry about it. Here's the deal; whether I shave everyday or every third day, this shaver misses a lot of whiskers. Even on the second and third passes. It does however provide a very close shave, but you have to spend a great deal of time going over and over the same area. It really bothers me that I have to waste the time to do this. My old rotary would clean 3-days worth of whiskers in under 5-minutes. My face is pretty tough since for most of my life I've also commonly used non-electric razors on a dry face to shave. The Remington shaver is also moderately loud. So far the battery charge has held up for about 8 shaves without recharging, and that is a good sign. I paid about $70 for this shaver and if it lasts a couple years then maybe it was worth it. Consumer Report had it listed as a recommended buy, but at this time I probably disagree with their assessment. Then again, I wasn't about to spend +$300 for the top of the line either. I'll just quit shaving all together.

I believe the electric shaver works best when the hair is quite short, hence the double treatment. The shaver works quite well in this process. I highly recommend it.   256. The item was purchased based on Consumers' Reports, which gave this shaver a high rating (\\"Best Buy\\"). The shaver was very loud and took a fair amount of time to get a close shave. It left long beard hairs untouched and they needed to be cut with the trimmer. I developed some razor nicks just like a regular blade and still needed to use styptic pencil. I have not had the same problem with three-headed rotary cutters and will go back to that style. The shaver was returned under the 30 day trial policy.
  257. I decided after many years of throwing money away on disposable razors and replacement blades (some are up to $3 per replacement set of blades or more) to opt for an electric razor. After consulting my favorite consumer's magazine/ website I decided on the Remington MS2-390. It was listed as a Best Buy and was only second to the Braun 360 complete which costs more than twice as much. I unpacked it, read the directions and plugged it in for its initial 24 hour charge per the directions. Two mornings later I tried it for the first time and was quite impressed. This shaver actually gives a closer shave than a manual razor and causes any irritation, if any. I tried out the retractable trimmer on my sideburns and was a bit disappointed in how sluggish it is to pop out. I think the retractable trimmer and the control for it needs a little design work. After a couple days the shaver was working great but on the third morning when I popped out the trimmer, I couldn't get it to go back in. It has two positions and I had it in the higher position which renders the shaver unusable. I called Remington's Customer Service the next business day and explained the problem. The person I spoke with was an English-speaking American in Madison, Wisconsin. I don't know about the rest of you but it's such a huge relief to get an actual American that speaks clear English when I call a Customer Service number. Anyway, she told me that the problem didn't sound serviceable and asked me to fax my amazon.com invoice to her and she would send me a brand-new shaver, free of charge and practically no questions asked. Good customer service is a big deal to me and Remington nailed it. I got my new shaver about a week and a half later, did the initial 24 hour charge again, and have been using it since on that initial charge which was over a week ago and I shave every morning. One thing to point out that a person unfamiliar with electric shavers such as was I may not know is that they recommend replacing the shaver screens every six months and the shaver blades every twelve months. I don't know if that is completely necessary but you may want to order replacement parts when you order the shaver and add that cost in when you're comparing products. I hope this review has been helpful.
  258. The Remington's electric men's razors are interesting, most especially given price/performance. I have a Braun \\"shaving system\\" (self-cleaning, using Braun's scented isopropyl alcohol, or any simple \\"rubbing alcohol\\") and an older model 3-foil head Remington men's electric razor which I clean simply by running that razor's foil heads in a cup of ordinary rubbing alcohol. I'm 76 years old and have an old man's daily stubble, which the Remington cuts closer than the Braun; the Remington having been rubbing alcohol emersed and cleaned and lubricated, than does the Braun system three times the cost. There's a cable / satellite TV documentary (also shown on YouTube) presenting the Braun men's razor manufacture. Informative, intertaining short programme. Given my success with Remington (and I have success with Braun, if at higher price/performance) I've moments ago bought through Amazon the premium Remington men's electric razor offered. Clinton C. Williams Oakland, Michigan USA
  259. I have owned several remingtons for the past 10 years approximately. I think this particular model has given an excellent close shave for the most part. Time will tell if the microscreens are durable. The one down side to this model is the noise. It is twice as loud as my last model.
  260. I have used an electric shaver for 30+ years and this Remington gives me the best shave ever. And at this price it is a bargain. You won't go wrong with this shaver.
  261. I've been using this razor for a few weeks now and I have been pleased with it. I don't grow much hair on my face, and the ones that do grow tend to be long and sporadic. There is a built in trimmer that has blades on both sides, which can optionally extend to the height of the screens to cut the long hairs at the same time as the stubble. This feature works really well for me, and negates the need to go hunting for the inevitable remaining longer hairs. The razor doesn't irritate my skin, and it doesn't pull any hairs. Another feature that I like is a red light will come on when the battery is getting low to let you know it needs to be charged.
  262. I bought this razor after reading about it on consumer reports and the reviews on amazon. I have to guess that CR tested it for a day or so, and the positive reviewers here wrote their reviews after a week or less. The \\"microscreen\\" is incredibly flimsy. Within 3 weeks, mine developed a slit that grew a little every day. The blades underneath contact your skin through the slit, and hack you up like Freddy Krueger. Then you need to replace the microscreens at $20 each. It's a good razor while the screen lasts, but if you need to replace it every month at $20/each, why bother?
  263. I tried the Remington MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable/Corded Men's Shaver for three weeks. I found the shaver to be uncomfortably noisy and to produce a substantially inferior shave to either the rotary Norelco (that I had been using) or to a Gillette that I occasionally used prior to the Remington. I returned the shaver near the end of the trial period.
  264. This razor is terrible. I gave it a big honest effort but it let me down with each use. I bought it as a replacement for a Nixon-era electric shaver that I dropped on the counter and it stopped working. At first I was pleased with this new razor as it produced a super close shave on my cheeks and sideburns. But, it sliced up my chin and upper lip with every use and my neck hairs are longer now than ever before. The manual said to give it time for my face to adjust, and I tried and tried to give it time, but I can't spend all day shaving - I have other things to do in life. I suspect if I started on Monday and took the time to shave every hair that it misses I'd have to start over again as it would be Wednesday or Thursday by the time it got it right. People have stopped me in the halls at work and asked if I'm growing a beard now. I'm not kidding, this shaver does that poor of a job. Add in that I'm spending over four-times as long as I was before to shave in the morning that now my scruffy face is late to work. Now add the fact that this razor is super noisy and that I can't get up before my wife to start shaving as I'll wake her up. Luckily I don't live near a grave yard as I'd worry about waking the dead. One of this shaver's positives was its battery life. I was getting two or three shaves per charge, which is well over an hour of total use between charges. I was expecting shaves to be 5-minute jobs like they were before, but with this shaver being so bad and taking so long I was spending about half an hour standing at the mirror each morning to get to the \\"partial beard\\" state when I'd give up. If the shaver actually cut hair in less time than it takes to grow back you would likely get a full week's use out of a single charge - and that would be awesome. And now you know why I'm returning my razor. I just printed out the amazon RMA and I am looking forward to a real shave sometime soon. Amazon shipping was super fast to get this razor and I expect the return to be handled just as speedily.
  265. This shaver works but it is a bit loud. It requires several rounds to approximate anything you can call smooth shave. It definitely does not compare well to Razor. The trimmer broke off after Nine months of intermitent use. I experienced occational nicks and pull until I started using the [[ASIN:B0009JDZTK Remington SP-4 Shaver Saver]] which not only stopped the pulls and nicks but also dramatically extended the life of the cutters and screen. I sprayed it on the cutters and screen after each use. Even though I purchased replacement cutter and screen units I never installed it since the original units were still going strong before the trimmer broke off. I have since resumed using Gillette Sensor Excel Razors.
  266. This is the best electric shaver I have ever used. It provides by far the closest shave and is the easiest to clean. Shaving time is about the same as with other electric shavers I have used. I have purchased a number of more expensive shavers (Norelco and Braun) over the past 40 years, so I was reluctant to even try a less expensive model. I went with Consumer Reports' recommendation and it was a winner! I would high recommend this product.
  267. Just two words, Simply awesome. The blade seems to go on forever. I am a hairy guy and my beard is thick too. I have been using this for 5 months now and still feels like new. Makes a lot of noise though. But has awesome power and outstanding performance.

  274. Purchased this shaver as a replacement for a similar model Remington. This shaver only lasted around a year before it started to be very loud and did not shave well at all.   275. When the blades are new, it gets closer than any other electric I've used. I've kept it for 3 years and been happy the whole time. But: -The trimmer is nothing special. It can handle when your beard gets too long to shave, but dont expect it to do any real grooming. -It's loud. I don't really notice it anymore, but if you're into having conversations while you shave, this isn't for you. -It can't handle long hairs too well. I have to be careful not to miss a stray whisker that this thing doesn't catch. Still, I'd say buy it. I really doubt there's anything at this price that's better, and I'm still happy with it 3 years later. You're getting more than you pay for.
  276. After using this electric shaver for about 1 month I must say I am really pleased. The shave, while not as close as a razor, is still good. I did a little research and this shaver, the Remington MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable/Corded seemed like the best for the minimal investment. It works very well, it holds a charge - a few times when I was running late in the morning, I took it along, and shaved later. It cleans up easy, has a nice pouch and brush along with the recharge cord. I reccomend this and I am known to be kinda sorta picky about items I buy. Very little down side to this shaver - its not a really close shave,but it is good enough most days.
  277. The reviews for this were basically this: - It's noisy - The trimmer is in a weird position - It feels slightly cheaper than the Braun - The shave is great - The cost is fantastic for what you get I've had it for a few weeks and have to say that all of the above is about right. I debated between this and the Braun, but I bought this because of all the negative reviews I read, none seemed to mention that it was a bad shave. So I figured even if I didn't like the trimmer or the noise, I'm still getting a good shave, and that's the most important thing. I actually don't mind the trimmer, and I don't think it's as cheap as some people say. It certainly is noisy, but a nice shave.

  287. I still prefer triple slotted shavers and wish Remington would bring one back. But, of several screen foil shavers tried, I've found this one provides the smoothest, most complete shave.   288. I purchase this item base on Consumer Reports recommendation and price. As stated in the report, the shaver is a little noisy but it does give a very nice close shave.   289. Most of my life I've owned various brands of 3-blade rotary razors. After my last Norelco's motor crapped out, I figured I'd try a foil model. After researching all the ones available on Amazon, I settled on this Remington MS2-390 as being the best buy. Pros: 1. The shave is much closer than I've ever gotten with a rotary. 2. With the dual long foils, I can cut giant swaths of beard at a time, without having to circle the area again and again like with the rotaries - the perforated foil seems to catch hairs that the rotaries would just pass over, especially in uneven areas where only a very small portion of the rotary would typically contact at once. 3. Shaving took about 2/3 of the time, and since it gets closer, my beard seems to grow less fast; with shorter stubble every morning, shaving goes quicker as the foil is able to pick up the stubble more easily. 4. Cordless and corded.. which means if the battery is depleted, you can still shave immediately by plugging without having to wait for it to recharge. My last shaver had this, and it was must-have functionality for my new one. Cons: 1. It is indeed loud, but is really only a problem when my wife tries to talk to me when I'm shaving closer to my ears. 2. It's much sloppier than a rotary - whereas the rotaries tend to trap most of the hair bits inside, this foil shaver seems to spray the bits all over, leaving little hair dots around the bathroom counter. 3. It's hard to get up close to your sideburns area - with the rotaries I could kind of push the hair I wanted to keep aside with the shaver as I cut the stubble, but since the foil is so tall it starts to trim back the sideburn hair. Overall I'm very pleased with my purchase.
  290. I've used Braun shavers for years & thought I'd try another brand. The Remington doesn't shave quite as close as a Braun and is louder but it also is about half the price of the Braun. I'm happy with my purchase.
  291. Very good electric shaver, easy to clean, extremely long battery life (I charge it about once every month and a half or so. Good shave, especially for the price. I have found that some of the pre-shave products like Lectric Shave help get an even closer shave.

  324. I bought my first Rem. MS2-390 over a year ago, and I decided to buy another before prices increase. It shaves closely, charges quickly, and is easy to keep clean. Run the battery completely down the first half dozen times to lengthen shaving time down the pike, (S.O.P. for any rechargeable device). I presently use a liquid pre-electric lotion. I may attempt to preclude an occasional whisker grab by replacing the liquid with the recommended powder. By the way, this razor holds its own with much pricier models. jotabe

  330. I owned the previous version of this razor for 5 or 6 years. I loved it so much that I used it until it literally started to fall apart. I actually taped it together in order to squeeze several more months out of it, as I could not find a replacement in any stores. I thought it was very strange: I was able to find replacement blades in stores....but never the actual razor. Now, I understand that Remington has decided to discontinue this wonderful razor (which would explain why I can no longer find it in stores). Although I don't understand WHY.<br /><br />The only razors I see in stores now are the super-expensive ones with the charging stations and all the \\"bells and whistles\\". Why do all new razors HAVE to be cordless with batteries? Does no one shave in the bathroom anymore (where a handy electric outlet is always nearby)?? I am really perplexed by this phenomenon. I don't understand what is the benefit of making ALL razors cordless. Can anyone explain this to me?<br /><br />Anyway, this very simple razor does what I need it to do: Give me a decent shave using a power cord. I don't need flashing lights, bells, whistles, pivoting heads, etc. I just need a razor that I can plug into an AC outlet and that can give me a decent shave for a reasonable price. This is it.<br /><br />I don't understand why, when a company makes a decent product, they always have to aspire to change it or \\"improve\\" it. A good product is a good product. I wish more companies would spend more time concentrating on QUALITY, instead of trying to fix things that are not broke.<br /><br />EDIT (6 July 2014): I went on Amazon this morning to make sure that this shaver is still available. I bought my current one back in April 2011, and love it so much that I was planning to buy another.<br /><br />IMAGINE MY SHOCK TO SEE THAT THIS EXACT SAME PRODUCT (which I bought in 2011 for $29.99), is now selling for $189.99!!!! Can anyone at Amazon--or Remington--explain how something that yousold for $30 three years ago, now costs over 6 times the amount? Can this be a case of realizing that the other $150+ garbage that Remington sells in the stores, are not as good as this very simplistic and functional design? So to cover costs of R&D and marketing of the expensive garbage that is not selling, Remington has jacked up the price on this item...because it IS ACTUALLY SELLING?
  331. I recently purchased this razor from Lords for $49 with free shipping and that was the best deal I could find out there. I bought it because of all the good reviews on here and because I have had two dud razors from Norelco back to back.<br />They are charging absurd prices for replacement screens and blades and I decided to ditch them just for that reason . I used to have a Remington MS2-250 and it did a great job so I decided to try the 390 ............ here is my review IT ROCKS this razor revs up big time and shaves closer than ANY razor I have ever owned . It recharges in an hour and I cant imagine any other razor doing a better job at any price . The reviews of it being slightly noiser than other is correct and I found that the noise is directly associated with the POWER and RPMS of this high performace razor............ so if you want quiet and dont cut good get a Norelco again but if you want something so you can throw the package of blades away and wont cost you a small fortune to replace the heads and screen then I cant recomend this 390 high enough it is the best I have ever tryed bar NONE!<br /> *****
  332. The product cuts well and the battery holds a charge for a long time. I charged the shaver when I received it and have had numerous shaves and haven't had to recharge it yet.
  333. It get's the job done and is an excellent shaver the only reason I gave 4 stars is because one time I was cleaning it the spring popped out and went into my sink.
  334. This is the first foil shaver that I have used. I have had it for three years and am very pleased with the closeness of the shaves and with the very long battery storage time and life.
  335. The battery on my previous MS2 390 would not hold a charge after two years. After pricing a battery change and new cutters, I order another 390. The new one works better than the old one with new cutters. Hopefully I will get better battery life out of this one.
  336. After 40 years of satisfactory service from a variety of Remingtons, I have found the one which suits me best. I shaves me fast, close and quietly. Each battery charge lasts for many shaves. It can be used AC or DC. It came with everything needed. Amazon did excellent job of shipping even sooner than expected with good communication to customer. Suggestion: Buy a back up screen and cutters at same time and avoid additional shipping fees. Bon chance.

  339. This shaver may have been rated highly but the decibel level is so high that it is nearly impossible to use. This level of noise can't possibly be acceptable for one's hearing. I'm amazed that these items don't have to pass a hearing safety review before they're put on the market when they are used so close to one's ears. After less than two weeks this shaver went right back to the store. It doesn't matter how close the shave is, although it pulled quite a bit anyway, it's not worth it at the risk of one's hearing. I wish I'd listened to other reviewers before I bought this shaver!
  340. I needed a razor for shaving in a hurray. This razor cuts the beard fine but it is very rough on the face. It does not scratch your face but has harsh edges on the razor head that is abrasive to dry shin. It has a very loud sounding motor also. Like always, you get what you pay for.
  341. This is the best electric razor I have owned in my 57 years on this planet. I charged it up and it ran at top speed for 2 weeks without slowing down. It's easy to hold and cuts really close, without nicking my skin. The trimmer pops up at two different heights, so you can use it for hard-to-reach places on your face. I've tried rotary razors, Braun microscreen razors and even the cheapo $10 razors at Walgreens -- and this one is the best. ~Larry Bodine
  342. At the recommendation of my oncologist I purchased this razor due to the anticipated treatment's effects on my facial skin. When I used the razor I noted scratches and bleeding on my now bald head and facial cheeks. Upon examination of the shaving face I found it was cracked with sharp edges. A letter was sent to the customer service department explaining the defect and requesting a replacement of that part; however, after six weeks they are yet to respond and I am stuck with a lemon. NICE!
  343. My Norelco gave it up after many years and I purchased this based on price and CR review. It is better than the last Remington I owed a while ago. It shaves as close as any electric but takes a little longer. I have had it a few weeks and it is still on the original charge. So good battery life. My biggest gripe, over the length of time it takes to shave, is the noise. It is much louder than the Norelco.
  344. I have had a few Remington shavers, and have actually liked them all.....except this one. It burns my neck, and it is tough to get a close shave with it. It leaves hairs, and then I have to go back, trim them, then shave the same area over again. I just don't like it. I am going back to the round cutter/triple head design. They work much better.
  345. I've had this shaver for about six months, and I'm happy with it overall. It gives a pretty close shave for an electric and is comfortable to use. The trimmer is useful too. It doesn't do so well with longer hair, so if your beard grows quickly and you don't shave every day, this probably isn't the best for you. It works fine for me even when I skip days though. I've had some missed hairs, but this is also reduced by shaving every day. The battery life is excellent at first, although I'm seeing noticeable decrease after only a few months. Overall, a good shaver. I'd recommend.

I especially like the trimmer as used on the MS2-390. It slides into position for use instead of a panel<br />flipping up like another Remington I have. As far as I am concerned, the flip up kind is worthless.I have two old Remingtons<br />similar to the MS2-390 that have worn-out trimmers which I am unable to repair. I have replaced the cutters and foils a few<br />times but am unable to repair the trimmers. It is unfortunate that parts for the trimmers aren't available as otherwise these<br />shavers would last most of a lifetime. I live in a rural area some distance from a town and other people. I don't bother to<br />shave unless I am going to town, so my beard gets too long for the foils. I must use the trimmer all over my face every<br />time I shave, so it gets more use than would be normal. I haven't had this shaver long enough to know how it will last ,<br />but I have no reason to doubt its long life like my old ones.

The replacement foil is even identical. One change I don't appreciate yet is moving the transformer from inside the unit to a more typical wall wart. This resulted in more space for the battery which explains the greater shaves per charge and, hopefully, an even longer battery life.

Fortunately the battery seems to be quite powerful. 2. The shaver tends to leave some whiskers that grow into long hairs over a period of a few days which is a new problen I have not generally encountered in my previous electric shavers. I use the trimmer while shaving to prevent this from happening.

  381. This is my first microscreen razor. It does a better job on my neck than my previous rotary razor. I don't care what anybody says, I've never had anything cut as close as a blade. The charge seems to last a long time, and it's nice that you can use it with the cord if the battery dies. It is a little loud, as other reviewers have noted, but its not unbearable. Overall, this seems to be a good electric shaver that gives a decent shave. I bought it because it was recommended by Consumer Reports and offered a good price compared to other electrics. I recommend it.

  388. I purchased this shaver for my husband for Christmas after much research. I was a bit nervous about some of the negative feedback (ie: too loud, doesn't cut longer hairs etc). My husband has a rough curly beard, and has suffered from ingrown hairs for years. Although it took about 3 weeks for his neck and face to adjust to it, most of his ingrown hairs have cleared up. This razor is not irritatingly noisy either. On a scale of 1 - 10, its about a 4 on noise level. Thus far, he's very satisfied with this product and prefers it over using a standard wet shaver.
  389. In this day and time, when people are traveling internationally for business and pleasure, it just doesn't make any sense for a shaver to not be dual-voltage. Plug this shaver into an outlet in Germany or the Middle East and you will fry it--as I did. I thought ALL such appliances were dual-voltage by now. My Braun 370 razor can be used anywhere. This razor is fine if you never leave the States, but you cannot take a long vacation or business trip overseas and recharge it without a heavy and bulky transformer. Remington needs to step up to the plate and make an electric razor that can be used anywhere in the world!

  391. When you see this many 1-star ratings, listen up. This is one of the worst electrics I've ever had. Keep shopping.
  392. I always assumed that the term \\"smooth and comfortable shave\\" was just marketing gibberish, but this razor changed my mind. I used a norelco XL for the better part of 10 years until it finally died. The difference between the 2 is incredible. This razor isn't as noisy as many of the reviews would lead you to believe. Where the norelco made a horrible screeching/grinding sound, this razor is more like a humming bird pleasantly flying around your head. The shave really is smooth and comfortable with little to no irritation. Conversely, the norelco would leave my neck looking like I'd been wrestling a cougar. I had heard that rotary razors handle long hairs better but I beg to differ after using both. The 2 position trimmer works great for finishing off those stubborn hairs that just won't stand up. I also love being able to get a nice clean edge on my beard. As others have said, it takes a bit of guess work with a rotary razor and was always difficult to get it looking nice (not to mention that if I got it to close it would just start yanking hairs). The maintenance of this razor is also much, much quicker and easier than my old rotary. I used to schedule time to disassemble and clean my norelco. Now, a quick brushing or rinse and lube and I'm good to go. The only place I can fault this razor is that the clippings seem to leak out a little while shaving. All in all I love this thing!
  393. This shaver works well, not excellent but quite well. Little noisy, comfortable to handle, quick charging, very similar to last shaver I owned from Remington that has lasted at least 15 years but I thought I could use a new one.
  394. The closest shave outside a straight edge. Obviously I like them. Holds a charge for me for 5 or 6 days. Get one you won't be disappointed.
  395. shaves well--bigest problem with mounting of the cutters, they come off too easily when foil is removed to clean.

  397. It's a great shaver. I owned Braun's for years. This is my first Remington and I'm very satisfied. It's a good product at a great value.
  398. I've been shaving with a traditional razor and shaving cream for 40 years. In a desire to change the routine and hopefully simplify, I was hoping that an electric shaver would do the trick. I was not willing to shell out more than $100, so I researched products that received high marks within that price category, and the Remington MS2-390 have promising reviews. So I bit. The process of shaving actually was more time consuming with the electric shaver than lathering up with shaving cream and doing things the old-fashioned way. I had to search out patches that had not been adequately cut, and with less than perfect eyesight, this proves a hassle. Finally, in terms of comfort and results, there was just no comparison - shaving with cream and a hand-held razor with good quality blades was far superior. In fairness, I can't condemn the Remington when compared to other comparable electric shavers; it was the only brand/type tried. Perhaps the more expensive rotary shavers provide a better experience. I ended up sending the unit back for a refund and felt like I had learned, once again, that there are no shortcuts to quality results.

  405. loud as hell...CR said to get it...they hit their head on this one...Never again on the cheap one. Try something else
  406. I have had my MS2-390 for several years. It's super! Gives a close shave and holds its charge for a LONG time (at least a week's worth of daily shaving), so if you are traveling on shorter trips, leave the charger at home! It also has separate foil heads, so when one wears out, you only have to replace it and not the whole thing, as many other shavers make you do. These also last me a long time. Here's another neat trick! I discovered that I can gradually rotate the cutting blades, so that as they get a little dull, just use a small pliers to twist the cutter a little bit (using the bit of \\"axle\\" that sticks out of each end). This does the same thing as replacing the whole cutter! I've been using my cutters for at least a couple of years. This model is also built for dual-current use, so you can charge it in Europe and other parts of the world.
  407. I had been using a Braun Shaver for the past 3 years. I was going to replace the microscreen and blades on my Braun, but I really did not like the way it was shaving. So I decided to look for a new shaver. I found the Remington MS2-390 and read the review and decided to buy it. I have to say it is the best shaver I have had in years. Great shaver at a really great price.

  415. Interestingly, this is the 3d one of this model that I have bought. Having the extra cords is handy for my travel kit. This one, however, gives an awful shave to point that it's about useless and so noisy that I think it will self-destruct from vibration. This thing should be taken off the market. I can't be bothered returning it - more trouble than it's worth to pack up and pay postage. For the moment I'm using old shavers that are infinitely better.
  416. I have had this razor for about two months now and I have gone back to my old shaver. I have had to replace the razor screen twice already. Not worth the cost considering the number of screen heads you will be buying with this model.
  417. Works well but way too loud and bulky; quality is on the low end and whenever you want to clean it, the head is falling apart.
  418. I've used electric shavers for close to 40 years. Braun, Remington, Panasonic, Norelco, you name it, I've tried it. I had a Braun that was doing a decent job but took a long time (4-5 minutes) to complete a good shave and get all the hairs. I saw the reviews on this shaver and decided to try it. When I first turned it on boy was I surprised at the volume! I don't have a dB meter, but it's loud enough that my daughter, upstairs in another part of the house, complains that it wakes her up. However, if it did a great job in a short time I'd be accepting of the racket. Alas it did not. It consistently left long hairs on my throat that I had to use the trimmer to get and then go over again with the regular foil. And on top of that, it was no faster than my Braun and shaved no closer - surprising because my Braun's head was 18 months old and the Remington was brand new. Does hold a charge well and fits well in the hand. I'm disappointed and going back to the Braun.
  419. Unfortunately, the unit I got had a broken trimmer so I am returning it. I may have returned it even if the trimmer wasn't broken because it is so loud and was only an average shaver. It took a few passes and struggled with a few day's growth. Probably performs fine on frequent shavers.
  420. My husband has mentioned how well this shaver works more than once and is glad I bought this for him. Actually I got tired hearing him complain about his old razor and the price was very good. Everyone is happy.
  421. I bought this shaver back in October and have been very happy with the purchase. In my opinion, the biggest asset this shaver has is its value. That's not to say that it doesn't perform well; it gives a close shave but doesn't set you back the hundreds of dollars other shavers do. Cleaning is easy. You just pop the top and use the included brush to clean out all the nasty bits. It holds a charge very well and has the ability to shave with the cord plugged in if it should die unexpectedly (I've not had to do that yet however). The only clumsy bit is the trimmer. It's just slow extending and kind of difficult to use but it's a small inconvenience. I wouldn't hesitate to buy another shaver just like this when this one does die but I'm hoping it'll last several more years.
  422. For the Remington MS2 390 I read a few reviews that said this shaver was made out of cheap parts and i overlooked them, I should have listened because it didnt take much time for the replacement blades needing to be changed and the 1st ones were fine but everytime new heads were put on the place that holds them is made out of plastic and gets worn out making keeping the new heads in place impossible.<br />If your only going to use this shaver for less than a year then go ahead
  423. This is my 2nd remington microscreen I've owned. My first one lasted for 5 years before wearing out. (I believe it was the Remington Titanium model).<br /><br />The battery life on these is amazing. I charge it once a week if not less. Its durable and its easy to take the blades apart and clean. I often just bang it against the edge of the sink. I have not had to purchase new blades or a new screen for it since I purchased it. The trimmer is great for roughing it out first or outlining the shape of my beard style.<br /><br />However, it doesn't shave extremely close and smooth. This suits my grooming style though. May not for others. Once the trimmer switch gets hair in it, it starts acting funny and won't always stay closed. You have to mess with it until it locks in place. This can't be taken apart and cleaned either.<br /><br />Overall, a very good, durable shaver.
  424. [[ASIN:B000H6A02A Remington MS2-390 Microscreen 500 Rechargeable/Corded Men's Shaver]] I have found that the face is easy to shave, but the neck, it will not shave this part. No matter which way I turn the shaver.

It is also easy to clean. As you probably know, it is the latest consumer report's best buy. It is also a little expensive compared to the Braun 1775, which used to be another CR best buy. All in all, I like this one much better.
  432. I've shaved with an electric razor for years and have used Remington's for many of them. For the past 10 years I have used other brands: Braun, Wahl, and Norelco, for example. Dissatisfied with the closeness I experienced with the other brands, I purchased the Remington MS2-390. While it is a little noisy, the closeness is unsurpassed. Because it does shave so close, it may be a bit irritating for those who are first time electric users; thus, may take some getting used to. As for me, it's perfect. I recommend it highly.
  433. Having owned a Remington MS3-2700 for a few years, I recently purchased the recent version, the MS2-390, for my son's 18-year milestone. \\"Consumer Reports\\" gave this new one a \\"best buy\\" (they can't be right all the time). Both shavers are easy to hold, run for several days on a charge, and come with a case and cleaning brush. They give a good, close shave. The downside to the one I've owned before is that it requires screen replacement more often than one would expect. These replacements are needed when one feels irritation during and/or after shaving, and the user notices a small spot or spots where the screen is wearing away. It only takes these tiny open areas to cause a problem. The replacement screen costs around half the price of a new shaver, so in time the money involved can be substantial. If Remington could find a way to keep the screen from deteriorating so soon, they would have a winner here. For now, rather than replace the screen again on my shaver, I have gone back to an inexpensive dollar store safety razor and foam. It will be up to my son to do what he wants once his screen starts going bad, but for me, I know how I'll be shaving.
  434. Overall, this is a very good shaver, however it is a little loud and seems to miss a few hairs here and there. Still, for the price, it is hard to beat. As long as it is kept clean and charged, you will be happy with the end result.
  435. My 12 year old Norelco rotary was due for new heads (tho its still shaved pretty well). I decided to give the Remington MS 500 a try as it did well in Consumer Reports and I thought the trimmer might work better than the Norelco's. The Remington trimmer is better for sideburns, but I had to use the trimmer for areas with difficult hairs on my face too --which was too irritating. So now I shave with the Norelco and trim with the new Remington.
  436. I've never used an electric shaver and this one works better than I expected. I bought it because Consumer Reports ranked it the best buy. They were right.

  456. This shaver met all my immediate expectations in terms of close shave, rechargeability, function and style. It is a close duplicate of the one it replaced. However, it does suffer from the same design flaw that I found in the older model. You absolutely have to keep the interior of the shaver swept out after each use. Even so, eventually whiskers are going to get down inside the workings of this shaver making the trimmer function inoperable in that you can't return the trimmer to its closed position. I use the Remington Shaver repair center nearby in Fort Worth, TX and even they could not get my older model to close after several years of usage no matter how much compressed air they used to blow it out. Evidently you can't just take either model completely apart and clean each component seperately. Built-in obsolescence? Maybe so, but expect to get only seven or eight years service from this shaver. Clean it regularly, use a rattle can of lubricant judiciously, care for it and it will give you many years of satisfaction.
  457. I started out using Remingtons years ago. I liked my first one, and I like this one. I have tried many others over the years, and despite all their claims, they do not do the things that count; and that is to give you a good, clean, fast shave. Most of them just grind the whiskers into powder over a period of many minutes. This one if a real little \\"chopper.\\"

  459. I have owned this shaver for about 6 months. It does a good job of cutting my whiskers. The head is thin enough to give a close shave.   462. I ended up purchasing this two times through Amason. Like others reviewed on here, the battery died. I probably used it 3 times before the battery died. NO PROBLEM THOUGH. I simply called Remington (as indicated in the manual) and they immediately shipped a replacement model #F5790. The replacement model has a swivel head which is nice. Anyway, I couldn't forget the very high rating that Consumbers Report give this MS2-390 electric razor so I still wanted it.....so I purchased it again through Amazon. Yes, I was concerned about the battery with my second purchase, but I have to say that it works perfectly fine with NO ISSUES at all. As for performance, well I see no difference between the MS2-390 and it's replacement F5790. They both work well. I know some reviewers complain about hairs left behind, but I haven't had that issue when used as instructed in the manual. Your hair/face/head/skin has to get used to the razor so give it time and actually use it during that time. Both units give a decent clean shave that I am happy with. One thing I did learn though, you should use the trimmer for longer hairs first. Use the razor to go over afterwords. Comparison to a razor: I still prefer a manual blade razor over these electric ones. The cut is faster and smoother, but not smoother by much.
  463. i bought this on march 30th from amazon. started using it straight away with the remington face saver powder. i was never that happy with the results (shaved everyday, minimum stubble) but persevered because i'd spent the money-also had nothing to compare it too. the noise of this thing is absolutely horrendous, i really think you could sustain hearing damage over a period of time. i stopped using it about 8 weeks ago-fed up with infernal racket & lack of a quality shave. since then i've now used a ten year old norelco, even that elderly worn out thing was like the difference between light & dark...i swear!! i've just ordered myself a new 7340 norelco & i'll update that in a few days/weeks & let people know how that's doing.

  468. I recently bought my first Remington and could not be more pleased. I have previously had several Brauns and Panasonic shavers. While the older Brauns were quite good, the newer foils seem to spoil my shave and don't cut as close. I have been pleased with the Panasonic Arc IV but wanted to try the Remington after reading some reviews. This shaver is a bit noisy and doesn't seem as well built as the Braun or Panasonic....but for me it shaves closer than the Braun Pulsonic and faster than the Panasonic for almost $200 dollars less. I think the secret is the foil. The foil really seems to have larger openings and consequently allows for a closer shave while the Pulsonic seems more geared towards comfort as it compresses so easily you can't really bear down. The dual blades of the Remington seem to cut both longer and shorter hairs as advertised and compress with pressure to allow for an even closer shave. Overall, I am very impressed....
  469. This razor does a great job. Very close shave and doesnt irritate my face. Just as close as a blade shave.
  470. I have used this product everyday since receiving it. The shaves I get are much superior to the ones I got with my older Norleco model. The trimmer is better designed and works well also. Battery life is great. I've only re-charged it once in 4 weeks.
  471. Given a high rating in Consumer Reports, this shaver lives up to its review. I have used various electric shavers for 20 years or more, and this one shaves faster and closer than any I've used. It won't cut up your face and it will save time. It recharges in an hour and can be rinsed with water. It is noisy and the protractable trimmer is awkward, and if these matters are important to you, then you might look elsewhere. But if a fast, close shave is what you're looking for, then you'll get a winner.
  472. Gives a good, clean shave although a bit loud. A good deal for the buck.
  473. Have used this razor since Jan.'08 and it has been performing flawlessly since then. The June '08 issue of a leading Consumer Magazine has just rated this MS2-390 a \\"Best Buy\\", second only to the Braun 360 at $170.<br />After the initial 2 or 3 charge/discharge cycles to improve battery memory, it provides me with over 20 three minute shaves every morning, which more than lives up to the advertised 60 minute run time. This will vary, depending how you choose to keep this unit charged. I run it down completely and use the cord to finish up if the batteries run out before I finish. Then recharge it for 24 hours for the next cycle. The red low charge light will come on about half way through and the speed will slow down perceptively during the last half of the cycle, but will still shave until batteries are fully discharged. If you use the quick charge feature, at least once a year fully discharge and then recharge 24 hours to prolong battery life. Be sure to brush the cutters and blow off the screens after every shave.(I do not recommend using water to flush out razor cutters.) Do not expect too much from the trimmer except to get the occasional whisker that escapes the daily shave or to trim the sideburns. It is too bulky to be of any further use. After all, this is a razor to shave whiskers with and not for haircuts and trims. This Remington should provide many years of use as did my previous one. Even after the batteries are fully depleted, this razor will still work via the plug-in cord.<br /><br />***** REVIEW UPDATE, April 16, 2011: I have just placed my order for another Remington MS2-390 Shaver to replace the one purchased in January, 2008. After a little over three years of daily service, the switch has broken and must be held in to keep the razor running. This has been the only mechanical problem so far, other than the battery run time has been declining over the past year or so, but that is to be expected with this type of rechargable battery. I have only replaced the screens once, about a year ago, and really probably did not absolutely need to do so at that time.<br />Why am I buying another of the same model ? 1. It has given me very good service every day, over the past 40 months and at a cost of $60.00 still comes out to be a fairly good buy. (about $1.50 per month). The second reason: When I purchased the first model at Amazon.com in 2008, I also bought an extra set of replacement screens and cutters at the same time. Let's hope the new one lasts long enough to actually need them. R. E. W.<br /><br />> > > > April 20, 2011 : Upon reading my Review Update of 4/16, it appears that the switch became inoperative due to a defect, when in fact it was the rubber cover over the switch that deteriorated and was about to fall off. In an attempt to repair it, I put a drop of Duco cement in between the switch and the rubber. After I did that is when the switch had to be held IN to work. Apparently I messed up the latching part of the switch mechanism by inserting the glue. My fault and it should be noted that the razor itself is still in perfect mechanical working order except for the switch. Sorry if I mis-led. R. E. W.<br /><br />* * * * September 14, 2011: An Ounce of Prevention. If you notice a slight deterioration of the rubber that is the switch cover, here is how to fix it.<br />1. Buy a bunch of fresh broccoli that has the stems held together with a wide elastic band.<br />2, Cook and eat the broccoli (it IS good for you) and save the elastic band.<br />3. Put the elastic around the razor to go over the switch. This should prolong the life of the rubber switch cover and if it should begin to go bad, it will hold it in place.<br />Hope this suggestion is of some value to those using this razor. R. E. W.he screens once, about a year ago, and really probably did not absolutely need to do so at that time. Why am I buying another of the same model ? 1. It has given me very good service every day, over the past 40 months and at a cost of $60.00 still comes out to be a fairly good buy. (about $1.50 per month). The second reason: When I purchased the first model at Amazon.com in 2008, I also bought an extra set of replacement screens and cutters at the same time. Let's hope the new one lasts long enough to actually need them. R. E. W. > > > > April 20, 2011 : Upon reading my Review Update of 4/16, it appears that the switch became inoperative due to a defect, when in fact it was the rubber cover over the switch that deteriorated and was about to fall off. In an attempt to repair it, I put a drop of Duco cement in between the switch and the rubber. After I did that is when the switch had to be held IN to work. Apparently I messed up the latching part of the switch mechanism by inserting the glue. My fault and it should be noted that the razor itself is still in perfect mechanical working order except for the switch. Sorry if I mis-led. R. E. W. * * * * September 14, 2011: An Ounce of Prevention. If you notice a slight deterioration of the rubber that is the switch cover, here is how to fix it. 1. Buy a bunch of fresh broccoli that has the stems held together with a wide elastic band. 2, Cook and eat the broccoli (it IS good for you) and save the elastic band. 3. Put the elastic around the razor to go over the switch. This should prolong the life of the rubber switch cover and if it should begin to go bad, it will hold it in place. Hope this suggestion is of some value to those using this razor. R. E. W.
  474. I last tried an electric razor 50 years ago, hated it, and have been skeptical ever since. After being a loyal blade user and dealing with nicks and irritation that led to skin breaking out, at the suggestion of a dermatologist, I tried the electric route using this model Remington, a Consumer Reports Best Buy. I was surprised to get a shave as close as with a blade the very fist time. My face feels a little tender from shaving against the grain, but it seems to be toughening up a little every day. This shaver gets an unequivocal endorsement from me!

  481. I had a DA-307 for about 7 years that I was relatively happy with when it finally died and I was not able to replace the internal batteries. So searching for a replacement I considered the rotary head style, but I remember having one before the 307 and preferred the foil type. The 280 model was easy to find in the stores, but oddly the 390 was nowhere to be found. And after the long workable life of my 307 I figured I had better go with the model with the markedly better reviews.<br /><br />I love it. =) It does a great job. As far as I can tell it keeps a charge for a long time. Out of the box it had a low charge and was functional, but I charged it overnight and then proceeded to use it for a full week without charging it up. At the end of the week, its low power light still had not lit up, but I figured that was long enough for a test. So I am pleased with the battery life<br /><br />The razor itself shaves nicely close - closer than the 307 ever did. The razor is on the loud side, but actually that helps wake me up in the morning.<br /><br />The only weak area I find really isnt even weak - just different. The pop-up trimmer is nicely wide and it cuts cleanly, but the mechanism by which the trimmer raises itself doesnt seem sturdy. However it has worked just fine. Also the trimmer blade can be a little tough on sensitive areas - lets leave it at that.<br /><br />So, all-in-all I am very pleased with this razor on both function and battery life.
  482. The Remington Microscreen rechargeable razor is a good product. It gives a close shave if you insure that you've covered all areas thoroughly. It does leave some longer sthat lay down against the face which you have to go back and cut with the trimmer. Following a 24 hour recharge the battery stays charged for about a week before needing to be recharged. Overall, I'd say that Remington Microscreen 500 is an 8 out of 10 when compared to a blade. It's quick and easy.
  483. Very good shaver with only two flaws. Noisy and bulky. It's still a gem compared to Braun for the price.
  484. My husband is very happy with it!!! Close shave, easy to use, is a little loud, but not bad. He's used a Remington shaver for years.
  485. Satisfactory, competent shaver. Well made, comfortable and solid-feeling. Gives a good shave in an average amount of time. Trimmer is unusually efficient. Can shave using its battery or plugged into wall, if you are negligent and let the battery discharge. One disappointment: Although you can briefly rinse the shaver (unplugged, of course!) to get rid of clippings, it is apparently not designed for shaving in the shower, as some electrics are. Water and shaving cream apparently can penetrate along the sides of the trimmer into the case, damaging or perhaps ruining the shaver. Still, in all, this is a good shaver and fairly priced.
  486. This razor from China worked so so for two weeks then died. Price was low and if it kept working I probably would have kept it. But now I think I will go back to Norelco, if they are still made in Holland.
  487. I ordered this shaver because of the 'consumer report' I had read on it. It's almost impossible to get a real close shave because it skips over some hair and no matter how many times you go over it, those same hairs remain.
  488. I initially bought a Braun razor and was very unhappy with it so I returned it to the store. I looked up the ratings on Consumer Reports and found this one recommended. The Braun was $35 and this one was $45. I am very happy with this one and at a reasonable price.
  489. Works very well, better than I expected actually. I had read other reviews describing it as \\"very loud\\", but I don't think it is very bad at all. The more often I am using it, the better the shave. I would definately recommend it.
  490. I bought this razor over six months ago on the recommendation of Consumer Reports. During that time, I haven't had a single issue with it. It provides a great close shave with no skin irritation. The charge is ussually good for an entire week of shaving and I occassionally shave more than once per day. Don't hesitate to buy this razor, you won't have any regrets!
  491. I ordered the Remington MS2-390 electric shaver. The order was handled efficiently and professionally. The shaver is superb, and I recommend it without reservation to others.
  492. Works well, seems solidly constructed and reasonable price. The shave is not particularly close, but it is painless even after several days of growth. Easy to clean and holds a charge for a long time.
  493. So far it's doing what it's supposed to do. It shaves reasonably efficiently, the battery holds up for over a week of shaves, and the low-battery light, which provides a 5-minute warning, is a nice convenience. The shaver runs at nearly full tilt until the battery is dead. Then it's easy to continue with the shaver plugged in. The adapter, however, is awfully bulky compared with some previous models.
  494. I purchased this to try on myself. I thought having something I didn't have to use in the shower would be nice. It didn't get the shave I thought I would. I read the reviews and they said it should work just fine for women. It does work fine but most women want a real close shave, everywhere. Disappointed.
  495. Thus far I have been pleased with the Remington MS2-390 Men's razor. No electric razor cuts as close as a blade, but the MS2-390 is close. For my beard, it outperforms the Braun Series 3 which I tried and returned. The charge rate and number of shaves/charge match the manufacture's claim. Clean-up is quick and easy; I add oil to the blades every other shave. On the downside, the instructions for the razor are incomplete (e.g., the blinking lights; the button you push to elevate the trimmer blade). The latter responds very slowly...like Phoenix rising from the ashes. And you have to manually depress it once finished. The shaver is also relatively noisy. Still, a good product for the price.
  496. Bought this shaver for my son because it was rated a \\"best buy\\" in Consumer Reports. My son has raved about what a terrific job it does. He has a tough beard, and he gets a really clean, close shave.
  497. I am a first-time user of an electric shaver so I don't have experience on electric-shaver performance. I have found this shaver easy to use and easy to clean. It works really well on short stubble; however, on a beard of any length at all, it's not so great. The shaver catches and pulls hairs, sometimes misses a patch of hair, and once I cut myself with it.
  498. I found that this shaver gave a very poor shave, particularly on the neck where the cutting heads cou;ldn't cut the outstandind hairs
  499. The MS2 390 Remington electric shaver is efficient, quick, and leaves no face shine. It's cordless, meaning I can shave and do other things at the same time.
  500. When I first received this electric razor, the power cord would not make a connection to charge it. I called Remington, and they sent me another one to my house within a few days. This razor works very well and shaves almost as close as a blade. The battery lasts a very long time, too.
  501. Both my husband and son found this shaver hard to use. The blades seem to not cut well. My husband had to travel over the same area on his face to get the stubble off. Also it is loud.
  502. Overall I am satisfied with my razor. I have a curley beard so I have to go over some areas more than once. I hve been using my razor about a month so I am getting better results each day.
  503. The shaver is noisy. Using a blade for many years makes it difficult to train beard to the electric shaver. More difficult than blade to get a close shave. Most of this was covered in pre-purchase data. [[ASIN:B000H6A02A Remington MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable/Corded Men's Shaver]]
  504. I hadn't used an electric razor for about 20 years, as the one I had previously owned seemed to \\"chew\\" whiskers off rather than actually cut them. I am quite pleased though by how well the Remington works- quick, close, and without razor burn. It isn't quite as perfect as a blade, but great for weekends when I just don't feel like going through the hassle of lathering up but also don't want to look like a vagrant by the end of the weekend.
  505. This is my third Remington Microscreen over many years of use, and they have all been excellent in performance and reliability.<br />People don't believe me when I tell them that it gives me a closer shave than I get with a blade, but it's true. (And that's even when I use new blades). I have tried other brands, but none have ever come close to the performance of this Remington.<br />I would have given it 5 stars except that this new model is a bit louder than the last version I had. But this is the one to get if you are looking for a very good electric shaver.

  512. My Norelco XL never seemed to do as good a job as the old Norelcos. So, I bought $250 Braun foil. It did not seem to do a good job on my neck. So, I bought a $25 Wahl. It vibrated a lot, was noisy, irritating, and did not shave as close as the Remington. The MS2-390 was rated a Best Buy in this month's CR. It shaves close and the irritation is tolerable. The screen is really thin, so it will probably need to be replaced every six months or so, but it is the closest shave I've had with an electric.

  516. I bought this shaver because (a) Consumer Reports designated it as a Best Buy (b) my own positive experience with the Remington CleanXchange and (c) the low price. Unfortunately, while the MS2-390 does deliver a close shave for me, it appears that the build quality of this model is suspect. The low battery light came on after just the 3rd shave and I began to notice small facial nicks after each shave, something I had never seen this from the CleanXChange and Braun foil shavers I also own. I know at least a couple of the other reviewers on Amazon have noted the same things happening with their shavers, so it's just not me having these issues. One gentleman on another forum has had Remington replace his shaver TWICE trying to get rid of the low battery light problem! It appears as if getting a reliable MS2-390 is just the luck of the draw right now. I have e-mailed Remington customer service about my concerns and will update my review if/when I receive a response. UPDATE: I received a replacment shaver from Remington Customer Service. However, I experienced the same issues as with the first model and have discontinued using the MS2-390.

  518. I purchased this item b/c of a recommendation from Consumer Reports. As they say it does offer a very close shave perhaps even exceptionally close for an electric razor (5/5). Having said this it does have few limitations. It is difficult to shave the neck with this unit (2/5); it has difficulty getting slightly longer hairs such as if you failed to shave over the weekend (1/5); the on/off switch is a bit clumsy to use (4/5); the sideburn clippers seem poorly designed and are clumsy to extent (2/5); but battery life is good (5/5). Overall the unit performs well but is not as easy and quick to use as my previous Remington triple head rotary. Overall score 19/30
  519. Purchased this based on Consumer Reports saying it was a \\"best Buy\\". So far it has not lived up to their rating. I am going to try using a pre-shave product from Remington to see if that helps in getting a better shave. As of now I would not recommend this shaver.
  520. This Remington is both inexpensive and rated very highly in a recent review by Consumer Report. I tried to buy it after I read the review, but apparently everyone else had read it, too, and the shaver was on backorder. When Amazon informed me it was available again I ordered it. Verdict so far (three weeks of use): excellent. It feels good in your hand, performs very well, and has a very good rechargeable battery (after three weeks I am still on the first charge). One thing that doesn't work as well as it should is the long-hair trimmer. You push a button to make it pop up, but instead it very slowly pushes it, and not always. Definitely a huge bargain.
  521. I purchased this shaver at the recommendation of a review in Consumer Reports. It arrived in just a couple of days from Amazon.com in perfect condition. I followed the instructions to prepare it for use, and immediately took it on a week's trip.<br /><br />The shave is remarkably close. While I don't think any electric can match a safety razor for closeness, this one gives my Mach 3 a run for the money. I shaved using my old Norelco rotary shaver after I had used the Remington for about 2 weeks, and I was amazed that the Remington beat the Norelco hands down. Nice and smooth, little 5 o'clock shadow.<br /><br />In other reviews, there had been comments about how noisy this shaver was. I beg to differ. It does buzz, but it is quieter than my old Norelco and not at all objectionable.<br /><br />The trimmer is fairly wide (the same width as the foil head) and is a bit awkward to use. It does work well, and has two height settings: the highest for straight trimming, and a lower setting to work in conjunction with the foil/blade section to get longer hairs while doing your regular shaving. I did find the trimmer to be hard to use when trimming my mustache, since it's wider and harder to control.<br /><br />After the initial charging period (24 hours), the battery lasts over 2 weeks on a charge, and takes only about an hour to fully recharge.<br /><br />Cleanup is easy--I usually just blow out the stubble daily, then use the brush once a week to get some stubborn whiskers out of the blades. You don't use the brush on the foil--just blow or rinse.<br /><br />In fact, I believe that most people that have problems with the foil failing could be from two reasons: pressing too hard while shaving, or using the brush to clean the foil. Hey guys, it's a thin membrane! You don't need to press hard with this shaver. I get a great, close shave with just a light, even touch.<br /><br />The shaver comes with a compact carrying case that includes a flap to separate the brush and cord from the shaver.<br /><br />The bottom line: This is a great shaver at a really great price. If you're looking for a shaver that will fill the bill and not cost you an arm and a leg, I'd recommend this one.er at a really great price. If you're looking for a shaver that will fill the bill and not cost you an arm and a leg, I'd recommend this one.
  522. I bought this shaver based on Consumer Reports' rating and it did not live up to their rating. I've used a Braun 1775 for several years and the Remington did not shave any closer and was extremely noisy. In fact, it is the loudest shaver I've ever owned. In addition, the trimmer is more difficult to use than on any other shaver I've owned. I decided to keep using the Braun and gave the Remington to my son.
  523. The shaver is somewhat disappointing. I used a very old Norelco and got equally satisfactory results. Remington leaves my skin irritated even with using their \\"face saver\\". Next shaver will be a rotating head type not screen.
  524. Bought this last month after leaving my ten-year-old electric at a hotel. Pros: It really does deliver a nice close shave. It's not quite as close as a blade, but it's darn close, and it's *miles* better than my old electric. The battery lasts a while, it's easy to clean, and the trimmer does work. Cons: The trimmer is fairly weak and somewhat difficult to get to work on rogue neck whiskers. Overall, it's a great product except for the trimmer.

  526. I needed something that was quality, I could leave plugged in without worry and was reasonably priced. this was it.
  527. Yes, the best shaver. I had a little worry at first about the battery discharging time and the somewhat inadequate user's guide, which didn't adequately explain the best battery charging techniques. I phoned a nice customer rep who explained the correct way - it's a NiMH battery, by the way - but battery discharging time didn't improve. A second call was greeted by an offer to exchange for a new shaver. I hesitated, because I didn't want to let it go. But they shipped a new one, I returned the original in the same package, and now I'm quite happy with the new one, which displays a nice battery charging/discharging characteristic. Let's hope they'll come out with an improved battery section for the \\"Use and Care Guide\\".
  528. I went from a rotery to this foil razor and I am very happy. The shave is easy on the face and cleaning is simple. Price and consumer reports review made my purchase of A new razor easy. If you want a clean close shave look no further then amazon.com and the Remington MS2-390 Microsheen 500.
  529. I bought this shaver to replace an old Norelco rotary shaver. CR listed it as a best buy and the reviews are great. I was VERY disappointed in the results. Each hair is cut by a row of blades vibrating very quickly, which by the way is very noisy. Each hair has to poke through the \\"microscreen\\" to get cut. I had lots of missed hairs and they are totally random. I used Remington Face Saver so the results should be optimum. To get a full shave takes me at least twice as long as it did with the rotary shaver. This shaver is probably good enough if you use it twice a day. That way the missed hairs will be less noticeable. This product is also VERY MESSY. Since the hairs are pulverized the \\"dust\\" goes everywhere when you clean it. I sent it back and bought a Norelco 8160XL. It was the same price as the 8140XL on Amazon. The cleaner is Norelco's way to get you to buy something (fluid) from them on a regular basis. I recommend the Norelco 8140XL.

  534. I purchased this shaver because of its top rating in 'Consumer Reports.' The shaver works very well. There are two minor drawbacks. First, it occasionally misses a hair or two on my beard. The wild whisker continues to grow until cut by the pop-up trimmer. The trimmer has two settings that easily cuts these stray beard growths, but this is an extra step that was not required by my older Norelco or Remington Shavers. The second problem occurs when cleaning the cutters underneath the head assembly. The cutters are not firmly attached to the shaver. In my opinion, this is clearly a design flaw. The cutters pop off quite easily when I simply brush the cutters clean. This was not a problem with my older Remington (TA-3070) shaver, and is the bigger of the two irritations.
  535. My husband loves this razor, but it no longer is being produced by Remington. If you want to try it, order now, as there will not be any more after their supply is sold.
  536. I've been using this shaver for about a month. I've used only regular razors before. This shaver is great. It cuts my beard shorter than a razor. My only gripe is that it doesn't cut the sideways hairs on my neck very well. I have to use the sideburns trimmer to get those. This takes a little extra time. I suppose one other gripe is that the leftover hair dust gets scattered all over my sink and makes for a big mess. But on balance I'm converted. I don't get any razor burn at all, even though the other kind of electric shaver (the twirling circular kind) gives me horrible burn and red bumps all over. The best part: no more cuts in the morning! No more blood or tissues or band aids. I'm very satisfied.

  554. When my 6-year old Remington MS3-3000 foil shaver needed replacement, I looked long and hard at what to buy. Strongly considered a rotary shaver but after consulting Consumers Reports - decided to stay with a foil shaver. While the MS2-390 has 'only' two foils instead of three and has no battery fuel gauge I took a chance on this shaver. GREAT choice. It shaves better than the MS3-3000 did new, providing 20 days of shaving on its first charge. An important feature to me is the ability to leave it plugged in while charging without worrying about over-charging and on that score, the unit actually has an undocumented feature - the green charging light blinks when charging is complete so you don't have to guess at that. Neither the Remington website, or their owner's manual admit to this feature but it is definitely there. After a month now, I am very happy with this purchase. The bonus? Six years after my first Remington Microscreen, this replacement was half the price of what I paid in 2002.
  555. This is the closest shave from an electric for me. Better than the Braun! And the cost is just a little more than buying a new screen and cutter blades for the Braun.
  556. Do you have trouble shaving day long or flat hair, or if you skip shaving for a day. My opinion, Remington gets a closer shave than Norelco. All in all, a great buy for me. Update 11/16/10: After owning this shaver for some time, I have experienced a problem. It still gives a wonderful shave. However, the run button stuck down and could not be released, so the shaver battery ran down. The shaver would still operate with the cord, but I didn't want to do that. Considering the low price, I bought another one. Same great shave. SAME problem. So far I've been able to releaase the button, but with considerable effort. I have small hands and fingers for a man, and may be depressing the button too far. Regardless, it should never stick down!!! I've bought my last one.
