  566. I bought this because reports stated it was the preferred shaver by both men and women, and the only real difference in shavers is the color and sideburn trimmer. The shaver does a great job without nicking the skin, and this is important because the recipient is on Coumadin, a blood thinner. Thanks to this smooth shaving razor she can enjoy silky smooth legs and underarms.
  567. My experience with this shaver and another of the same model I got on sale is that while it gives a great shave you will go broke replacing the foils. Instructions tell you to replace the foils every 6 months. I find they rarely last more than 2 months before a hole develops. Use the razor with a hole and you will get pinched or cut. After calling Remington I was told that perhaps I should use a rotary razor as my beard may be tough. Well my beard while not heavy is wirey but only a little more than average. Remingtons advice leads me to believe that foil razors are not robust enough on anything more than fine hair. By the way, those foils cost $30 per set because they come included with new cutters. They are packaged as a set so there is no option to buy just the new foils. Guess I'm going shopping for a rotary and probably not Remington.
  568. This does shave very close. But you have to make several passes in different directions to get the close shave, otherwise it actually skips whiskers.
  569. I purchased this product for my dad and he stated it did not cut his hairs very well. I thought it may have been a good product as consumer reports rated other models from this brand as good but I guess I have to purchase the exact model which was tested. I do not recommend purchasing this item.
  570. This electric razor is priced well. It is noisy, but in the abscence of time or a traditional razor and shaving cream it works well enough.
  571. I read all the customer rave reviews on this shaver which led me to purchase. I've had it for over a month and quite frankly, I'm disappointed. I've always used expensive Norelco's in the past and have had no complaints with them. I'm retired so I don't have to shave my tough beard every day. Number One: If you are like me this is not the razor for you. If your growth is a couple of days old, expect to spend quite some time in front of the mirror. This thing takes forever and really does not give a close a shave as my past Norelco's. Number Two: It is very noisy. Number Three: The pop up trimmer does not 'pop-up' I have to pull it up to use. Any body want to buy a slightly used Remington? I'm going to order another Norelco.. Ted Evans Cape May, NJ
  572. After 25 years of using Norelco Rotoray razors, I decided to try the Remington Microscreen razor based on the highly rated review by Consumer Reports. I was very disappointed. It is very noisy, awkward to hold and shave with the rotating motion as recommended by Remington. It does not give a close shave either. I have now gone back to my old Norelco Rotary and am happy.
  573. This Remington electric razor is great! My husband is very happy with it, therefore I am happy too! No more complaining about the 'other' razor. It's replacing one that I paid $135.00 for which was a waste of money.
  574. I purchased this electric razor to replace my rotary of 15 years. I have found it to be noisy and pinchy. It holds a charge well for at least a week, which is good. However, it does not shave much better than my old rotary for which I have never replaced the blades. After trying this razor for 2 weeks, I will go back to a rotary, because it shaves at least as well with much more comfort and no pinchy feeling. A real disappointment. Aurora, OH
  575. After my previous experience with a rotary shaver product, the Norelco 7340, I left a very positive review--too soon, it turned out. I was soured on that product only a few weeks later, as the shave quality rapidly deteriorated. But I wasn't ready to give up on a perfectly smooth shave without hacking my face to ribbons. Fortunately, the Remington MS2-390 fits that bill perfectly. This razor shaves me in about 3-5 minutes. I rarely have to go over a spot more than once or twice, and it even does a good job on the neck area. But the real selling point is that this shaves me closer than a blade. I can run my fingers over the shaved skin and feel no grain whatsoever--my face feels like a very high-quality soft leather, perfectly smooth. I've never gotten this close with a blade; even if I shave against the grain I'll get razor bumps and irritated skin. Unlike with the previous electric razor product, I've had this one for three weeks now (through almost two complete charge cycles), and remain just as satisfied as the day I bought it. I don't see myself replacing this razor for a good long time. *** Another quick note -- judging from the widely varying reviews that I've seen for all electric razors, I think the quality of the shave really depends on the interaction between the razor and the individual's beard, face, and technique. This one works exceptionally well for me; it may not work for you. If you want an electric razor you can use as a main shaver, you'll probably have to try a couple. Most have refund deals; don't be afraid to use them. A word of warning -- this one's refund offer is 30 days, not 45, so make sure you make your decision fast, and don't interrupt the break-in period at all or you won't be able to get through the adjustment phase before the refund expires.
  576. had the previous model for 20 years. finally needed to replace it. works great. glad remington didn't stop making just gave it a new color and number.
  577. I believe for the price that this is an excellent Razor. Yes it is a little noisey and does not have a convenient recharging system (you have to plug it in). It does, however, deliver a close shave in a timely manner.
  578. Great razor but battery died after 2 years of use. I recommend a razor with Li battery if you can afford it. My current razor stays charged for 2+ weeks (as opposed to 3 days with this one) and has been working for 3 years.

  581. This is my fourth Remington shaver. Overall I love this style of shaver and will continue to use it. This one in particular has a terrible battery. I get one good shave out of it before having to charge it.<br />The only good news is it uses a basic AA style battery, but it's not straightforward to change. You better have decent small-device repair and soldering skills. I plan on replacing the battery with a Sanyo Eneloop soon.
  582. I'm on to my third or fourth MS2-390. It cuts better than anything else I've used, but its Achilles' heel is the battery.<br /><br />My beard is coarse. The whiskers stick close to the skin and will actually form ringlets if allowed to grow, rather than extend outward. I've tried other brands (Norelco, Panasonic, Braun), but they all have more trouble lifting the longer whiskers and cutting them off than this Remington.<br /><br />My previous MS2-390s all had short battery life. I never got more than two or three days use out of a charge, contrary to what some people here have reported. (I must use mine for a longer time every morning.) With the current one, which I bought in December 2012, I decided to leave it plugged in all the time to avoid the problem. Using it while plugged in hasn't been much of an inconvenience for me.<br /><br />But now the shaver refuses to accept a charge. After leaving it plugged in a while, it will blink green, indicating a full charge, and then turn red as soon as I turn it on, even if plugged in. It also sounds as if the battery has run down. Obviously, even when plugged in the shaver uses the battery and isn't running directly on household current. Maybe the battery would have lasted longer if I had &#34;exercised&#34; it by running it unplugged.<br /><br />I just tried my old Braun, which is about five years old but in nearly new condition because I used it only a few months before buying another MS2-390. It again had trouble lifting longer whiskers. So I will be buying another MS2-390. Wish me luck.
  583. This new razor shipped fast, was well packed, and came in its original package. It is light, powerful, and able to trim with its trimmer, as well as shave me. Because it is rechargeable and can produce a number of shaves with each charge, I take it on my travels everywhere. And it comes in a nice small case that fits easily in my shaving kit or briefcase. This is a replacement for the same, but more basic model of the Remington razor I had been using. Many years ago I fell in love with this design Remington razor. It consistently gave me the best shaves I ever had. Even though I have tried many other brands and different Remington razor designs over the years, this is still the best I ever used. This order was to replace a previous version that has finally worn out. As you can tell, I'm really sold on this razor. My highest recommendation!

  589. I replaced my 10-year old Remington Cordless shaver as it had worn out with this. It is noticeably lighter, but has the same microscreen and blades my old unit had. It shaves very nicely, and closely. It is rechargeable, and generally lasts me about a week to 10 days before needing charging again. Much of the unit that was solid plastic or metal on my old Remington, has been replaced by cheaper plastic or rubber. The plastic holders that hold the blades in place inside the microscreen have begun to fail after a year. And the on/off switch which is a button under a raised plastic push cover has worn out and the plastic push cover fallen off. The old switch was built considerably stronger. I am disappointed that the shelf life is apparently going to be so much shorter compared to the old model. This one is due for replacement already. I like the way it shaves. Now if it would just hold up a few more years . . . !

The shaver is extremely noisy, I had to close the bathroom door not to wake up others. The material is cheap and the plastic starts peeling of after just a few months. The shaver smells funny when you first get it, like it's from a factory that uses highly toxic materials. I did like it that the beard trimmer could be used together with the normal shaving head, so that it would cut stubborn neck hair easier, and you get a few less ingrowns than the Norelco. This worked OK for a while, but then the pop-up trimmer broke, so now I need to buy a different shaver.

So, I changed my habit on that, but the buttons are unnecessarily large to release the screen. The trimmer seems to be cheaper quality than the earlier model Remington that I had. This one of those fancy looking \\"they-don't-make-them-quite-like-they-used-to\\" products. BUT, YOU KNOW... it shaves the face. I have gotten used to it and it works in the morning when I need it and it charges fast and well, its a pretty inexpensive electric razor and I needed a new one. So, it works.

  607. I waited six months so I could use the 390 and give an good honest review.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1. Good, clean, smooth shave.<br />2. Easy to clean.<br />3. Fast charge time.<br /><br />Cons:<br />1. Sounds like a gas powered weed blower and/or model airplane motor - yeaaaaiiaaaeea - on my face. It is loud and noisy! And, no, I don't get used to loud noise at any time of day. Loud is loud. Period! I guess Remington forgot the old saying \\"A nice quiet morning shave.\\"<br />2. Cheap foils! I have gone thru 3 sets of foils - book says once every 6 months - in 6 months which now surpass the cost of the entire shaver. No warning as they break while shaving. What you feel is a cut/gash or two [1/4-1/2\\" long] as the broken metals scraps against your face.<br />3. Fails to shave fine neck hairs no matter how hard you press or stretch the skin. Only my Norelco Rotary or double bladed Gillette disposal does the job.<br />4. The cutter is useless. You cannot see your trim line.<br /><br />Forget Consumer Reports as they test on dummies not humans. Would I buy again? Not in this life. As like the Braun, the Remington foils are thin cheap metal and break easily. If they made better foils and a much quieter motor I would consider but only after firing it up in the store.
  608. I received this from Remington as a replacement for a shaver that i liked that broke. After not being initially happy with it compared to the one i sent back, I started to like it because it had a close shave. It did not take long for a foil to start wearing away on one end. I have never had this problem with any other foil shaver. If you don't want a extremely noisy shaver that makes you buy foils routinely in order to use the shaver, don't buy this no matter what the price. You are better off buying a better shaver that does not wear away foils so fast.

  621. Having used the Remington MS280 previously (2 shavers) I found this model to be the successor of MS280, with some upgrades. It gives a good close shave, is not quite as loud as the MS280, and has retained the pop-up trimmer that goes straight up to line up with the cutting foils (rather than flip out at a 90-degree angle which does not do as good a job of trimming). Let's hope Remington keeps this design in production, as I had a lot of trouble finding it on the internet. I've used it now for over a year and there is one drawback: the charging wire is very thin and may have broken at the tip that inserts into the shaver -- you have to fiddle with it to keep the connection.
  622. Like almost all other electric shavers I have owned, it does a great job for about the first 3 weeks until the foil and blades wear out. Then, for the mere price of close to $50 to $70, you can order new foil and block if you want to return it to its original effectiveness. There are third-party foil/block makers for this model, and if you go that way, you will pay $30-40 for a new foil/block, and it will last you 2 weeks instead of 3. Other big issue -- clippers stopped working in less than one year. Next issue -- simply the loudest, noisiest shaver I have ever owned.

  637. In the last 8 years I have used two GRUNDIG shavers and liked them very much. Now that Grundig shavers are not available in the USA I thought I should try an electric shaver that was made in the USA. Therefore, I decided to buy Remington MS2-390. But I regret that I did. Compared to Grundig it is bulky, heavy, not well balanced in hands when shaving and extremely noisy. Most of the shaved hair fall out of the shaver and on my chest, belly and the sink. A few times I barely touched the foil release button inadvertently and the foil assembly fell off. It has a tendency to pull hair while shaving. The side burn trimmer is very sharp and can easily cause skin injury while remaining practically useless in trimming the side burn. This shaver gave only slightly closer shave than my Grunding 6595 shaver. But again my Grundig shaver is two years old with the original cutter block and foil. The design and workmanship is crude. Compared to Grundig, MS2-390 is a toy. I will not recommend this shaver to anybody and will not try any other product from Remington again. I will not take a chance. If Grundig can make a fine product why not Remington. I would rather buy an American product but it does not mean I will just throw away my money. I am already looking for another shaver to replace my MS2-390. But this time it is not going to be Remington.
  638. I recently shaved off my beard of 25 years, cause some made a comment, that it made me look 60 years old, and I couldn't have that, cause I'm ony 57. I didn't have the ZZ top kind, but a some what trimmed one. So I still had to shave my upper cheeks and my neck and always had a hard time around the adams apple area. Regular razors always cut that area and most of the electric razors never did a good job of shaving close enough. But while reading my new X-mas edition of Consumer reports, it had the top pick for price and shaving features. So I bought one, and I love it, it shaves as close as a regular razor and best of all no shaving nicks or irration and I don't look 60 anymore. So if you have sensative skin, this is the one..............
  639. I can see why Consumer Reports consistenly rates this razor so well. It handles all of the basics and does them so well. I am very impressed with the battery life and especially like the ability to plug the shaver in and use it while the battery is recharging. The shave is extremely smooth.
  640. This shaver is a wonderful bang-for-your-buck. It comes with a charging cord, small cleaning brush, travel case, and shaver. It works wonderfully on the cheeks and jawline, although it still misses a few stray hairs on my neck from time to time. From my experience thus far there are no serious defects or problems with the shaver and has been simple to use on a daily basis. I would highly recommend this shaver to anyone looking for a medium-priced electric foil shaver. The reason I gave this product a 4 out of 5 is because of the following reasons. Negative signs mean negative reasons and positive signs mean positive reasons, neutral observations/reactions are denoted by a tilde \\"~\\" ... - assuming a 5 star rating is a spectacular product that is perfect or beyond expectations, this shaver falls just short of that, hence 4 stars - it does inevitably miss one or two hairs under my chin and lower on my neck every once in a while (not frequently) - in order to maintain a clean shave from day to day I find that I have to remove the cover of the head unit to brush out accumulated hairs from the blades and from the foil screen - I would prefer having less maintenance for an electric razor - a little louder than I would like it to be ~ foil head/blades last 3-4 months - having to replace foil head/blades is annoying and can increase the cost of using the shaver + life of foil head/blades lasts significantly longer than some other shavers I've used before + the noise it creates is less than other electric shavers I have used in the past + small and portable + battery lasts for several days (about 6-7, depending on frequency of use during day)of morning and nightly use + battery charges to full capacity quickly and within an hour or two + included travel case is functional and appropriately sized + included travel case has an intuitive flap to protect the charging cord from scratching the body of the razor + included brush has two sides: one sidewith long brushes for reaching between the attached razor blade heads and one side with shorter and firmer brushes that wipe away more hair + included foil head protector is a nice addition and serves it self-explanatory role effectively + shaver fits nicely into the contour of your hand whether you grasp the whole body or whether you more delicately handle it with a few fingers + trimmer blade cuts down longer hairs with ease + trimmer blade pops up mechanically via a release button near the blade itself, otherwise it stays hidden from view and does not interfere with regular daily shaving needs + relatively inexpensive for a quality electric foil shaver I would recommend this product to a friend any day.
  641. I bought this because Consumer Reports said it gave a very close shave; most of my shavers always left more bristle than I wanted. And they took too long. This I found truly fast, truly easy to clean, and it gives a genuinely close shave. I know that most electric shavers aren't nearly as good after a year or so as when they are new, and I've only had this a short time. But I do love it, at least for now.
  642. I'd been a Norelco shaver for years, but am really enjoying my first Remington electric razor. This one is a great value. As the other reviews of it I read indicated, it's a little on the noisy side. But it gives a close shave, a charge lasts at least two weeks, and it takes only an hour to recharge the battery. We'll see how the cutters, screens, and razor itself hold up over the long haul.
  643. We checked out several electric razors and found the Remington MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable to be a great buy. Now that we have it we love it. It's easy to use and shaves much closer than we though it might. Try it out for yourself.
  644. I have been using this razor for three weeks and have found that it does a great job. I love the fact that this razor can be used as a battery pack or as a corded electric shaver. I would recommend this razor to anyone who is looking for an electric shaver.

  646. This is my second Remington electric razor. My first, an MS2-290, was slowly dying after years of tough service. I decided to upgrade to an expensive Norelco Arcitec. I was completely disappointed with it. It took longer to shave and did not cut the hairs nearly as close, even after about a month of use. I have now switched back to a Remington foil razor (at a third of the price) and am completely satisfied.
  647. The machine is good. It shaves good not like a razor would, but it's close enough. The grip is good, and the cleaning is easy. I have no problem with the machine, and I am content with it.
  648. This was a very highly rated shaver in a consumer rating magazine. And it does a reasonable job of shaving; not great, as I find that every few days I have to go over my face with a blade razor to catch the odd missed hairs. But that's not so uncommon for electric shavers. However, the screen is very delicate. After a couple of months it broke and I had to replace it. Since then I have religiously used the plastic protective cover when the shaver is not in use, but this morning I discovered (painfully!) that the screen was broken again. I'm giving up on it; replacing screens every few months is too expensive.
  649. This is a great shaver! Close shave - long battery life. A little loud, but not loud enough to annoy anyone through a closed door.

  651. This is my second one of the same model. I love it. Would recommend it to anyone. Remington is the best
  652. I was looking for a shaver to replace a ten year old one I have and love. Finding an electric shaver that works well for YOU seems to be a very subjective venture. What works great for me may not be at all suitable for you. I purchased several shavers of several brands looking for one that works well for me with no success.<br /><br />Finally I decided to look for a shaver that uses the same foil/cutters as my old one by searching Amazon. This is it and I love it. The battery charge life is fine, but for me it's somewhat less than advertised. The number of shaves they claim on a charge vs battery life would mean they expect you to complete each shave in four minutes. I cannot, it takes me about 12 minutes per shave so I don't get anywhere near the number of shaves per charge they mention. That's not a negative comment against them, simply a statement about MY shaving.<br /><br />The only negative is it does not do well for me on more than a day's growth.<br /><br />The low battery warning light is a big plus as ni-cad batteries give you no indication they are getting close to discharge by slowing down. They just suddenly stop. Recharge time is quick also.
  653. I bought this to replace my 20+ year old Remington shaver when the battery finally totally died, I am happy with it.

I shaved and shaved with it and hairs were simply not coming off my face compared to my old floating heads and as other reviews have mentioned you can not simply get any hairs off your neck at all. I stood and marveled at how I could shave for 15 minutes with an electric razor and look like I really needed a shave.   679. My first was purchased around 2007 or so when a consumer magazine rated it a best buy. It was very noisy and shaved really close; so close that I frequently got razor burn and some nicks and cuts till I learned the best way to use it. I have had a problem with the rubber cover over the on/off switch coming off. I tried to replace it by glueing if back on; BAD decision as this ruined the switch on # 1.<br /><br /># 2 and 3 gave good close shaves, but were also noisy, and caused razor burn and eventually the rubber cap over the switch wore off. This time I didn't worry about the rubber cover and just kept using it till the switch finally gave up the ghost. On # 3, The recharges were not lasting that long, the rubber switch cover fell off, etc., so I ordered # 4 from Amazon in June 2012. However, # 3 just kept on working well until around March 1, 2014 when it just quit. So I broke out # 4 which I had purchased 21 months earlier, and I could not believe the difference!!! # 4 is so much quieter that I thought it had a defective motor. But it is giving wonderfully smooth, close and comfortable shaves and NO razor burn as with the first 3. It looks exactly the same as the first 3 razors, but this one is an entirely different animal as for noise level and closeness of shave with no cuts nor razor burn. And the battery seems to hold a longer charge/run time. I don't know if Remington has reengineered the 390, but for whatever reason, # 4 is perfect in my book, and I would give it SIX STARS if possible. I hope I will be as lucky and happy with # 5 when that day eventually comes.<br /><br />navydoc

I usually shave with the old style, non-electric razor using shaving cream or gel. I only used this razor to remove a 1/2 days growth in the evening before going out and that is not very often. Within 2 dozen uses one of the screens tore. This made the device completely unusable. Because I would seldom use this razor, too much time had passed to return it. It sat on a shelf for about 6 more months. Each time I would open the door to the cabinet and see it sitting there I would think to myself \\"piece of junk\\". So - finally i decided to purchase a new screen. I could not find it locally so I found it here on Amazon. The reviews said the after market replacements were not that great so I found the replacement screen made by Remington. The problem is the fact that you cant buy just the screen(at least I couldn't find the original Remington version). You have to buy a kit that includes the screen and cutters. that was $19.95 plus shipping. So I spent almost half as much to replace the prematurely worn parts as I did to purchase the entire package. As you can tell by reading this I am not very pleased with the purchase of this item. I would not buy it again and I would not recommended it to anyone.

  683. I've been using Norelco shavers for more than 20 years. When I reviewed this product it said everything I expected to be said. This part is especially true: this is a verrrrrry effective shaver. It has cut my shaving time by at least 50% and improved the end results 300%. Very smooth. However I do not recall anyone mentioning how loud this product is but IT IS LOUD. As a result I can no longer shave while I'm on the internet if my wife is, as is usually the case, still asleep 30 feet away in another room. BTW: I discovered a great way to clean shavers. I use a pressurized can of Dust Remover. You know, the stuff for spraying keyboards etc. It does a very effective job and fast too.<br /><br />February 2013: All the facts above are true HOWEVER I have switched back to Norelco. Replacing the dual screens on the Remington was very tricky. It was so bad that the last time I tried to replace them I damaged one. After buying a set of two I was not in the mind to go buy ANOTHER set of screens and take the chances of ruining another screen.<br /><br />So, I switched back to Norelco. It's fine, quiet and surely will be quicker than the other when it's time to replace the cutters.

  687. I love this type of Electric Shaver. It gives a very close and smooth shave! This is my third one that I've had in my life! I recommend it to every man!
  688. This shaver is what I use daily. It shaves my beard skin-close and as a rule doesn't irritate. With this shaver I do NOT get \\"5:00 shadow\\" caused by too light a shave, nor do I get the \\"plucked feathers\\" sensation caused by too heavy a shave. It runs roughly two weeks between charges, and even when it needs a recharge it shaves very well.<br />Highly recommended and constantly used. This is a good shaver for not a high price.<br /><br />May 24th 2014: There seems to be an inherent problem with this razor. I've had two of them and both of them have exhibited exactly the same problem. The cutters fit into a sort of \\"pinch\\" retainer that is attached to the razor's shave system. In two cases, the innermost cutter attachment unit (nearest the trimmer) has loosened to the point that the cutter falls off when you remove the screen to clean the shaver. This problem has happened to two shavers, virtually identical in every respect, one being purchased as a replacement for the other. It is NOT the cutter. Switching cutters does not fix the problem; the difficulty is with the cutter attachment point. Since this is a second failure, I will be replacing the shaver with a different brand. Why? When the cutter becomes loose enough to fall out when you remove the shaver head and screen, it becomes loose enough to start abrading the screen itself, which will fail in a few weeks of shaving.<br /><br />While I like this shaver, I don't like what appears to be a design flaw (exactly the same problem, exactly the same place, times two) in the system. Too bad. I really liked this shaver but since it appears that the entire line uses the same sort of attachment, I will probably be switching brands. Sad, sad; this is a nice razor with a serious problem.<br />P.S. Replacing the cutters and screen accomplished nothing whatsoever. The inner cutter kept falling off when cleaning the razor.

  699. I think that Remingston was one of the best shavers made. My first shaver was solid and shaved well. I had no complaints. So I read a review on the new Remington shavers and chose the Remington MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable/Corded Men's Shaver. It shaves well, but when I opened the package after purchase, I found that the shaver head was warped. Remington sent me a new head. Then I used the trimmer, which pops up at the push of a button, and I could not get it to stay down after pushing it back into the closed position. I really had to work to get it to close and lock.   701. Before this shaver, I had a Remington 3-head foil shaver, which gave a very close cut. This one is almost as close, but that's enough to still have a smooth face afterwards - and, it retained all other characteristics of the 3-head version: no skin burns, fast shaving performance, easy popup clipper and charge holds reasonably. Have tried various foil shavers by Braun and even Remington since retiring this one and none of them can compare in terms of shaving quality, speed, comfort or value. Wish that they simply evolved this type of design instead of moving to dual foils that are separated by a wide space - keeping the foils close together seemed to be a primary reason this worked so well. I've recently unretired the shaver until a suitable replacement turns out to be worthwhile, though it needs to stay plugged in because the battery just won't hold much charge after so many years.
  702. I've always liked Remingtons, and this is no exception. It shaves close, is lightweight, and is comfortable in my hand. An eventual drawback -- It runs only off the battery, and not direct power. When the battery finally goes bad you can't run the razor.

  706. I used a Remington MS-290 for many years and was pleased with it until the rubbery cover over the power switch finally separated from the surrounding gripping area. Although that unit still works if I keep a rubber band over the switch, I thought it would be nice to move up to the MS2-390 which has the ability to be used with a cord when the battery is drained. That's the main difference between the two models. Sadly, the quality of the new razor is not as good as the older one. The protective dust cap doesn't fit at all well (I swapped it with my older one), the plastic foil assembly seems flimsier and doesn't snap into place well, and the buttons for the popup trimmer don't operate every time. (The buttons for the trimmer on the older model that is many years old still works properly.) The MS2-390 still gives a good shave, but it's very disappointing that something that's new doesn't fit together as well as something that's many years old.
  707. This is a great shaver. Have tried the other brands and frankly they do not shave clean. This model holds a charge at least 2 weeks of every day usage.   711. The old shaver wouldn't hold a charge, and the cord became increasingly difficult to seat properly -- and this was a replacement cord. We finally decided to check out what CU had to say (May 2008 issue?), and this Remington MS2-390 Microscreen 500 was near the top of the report. Be careful, however, as Remington has a lot of models with similar numbers -- we didn't find this model in any local store, and purchased it online. The shaver is compact, light, comfortable to hold, and it shaves surprisingly well. It is easy to clean (one can even use running water, although we haven't tried this). We have carefully followed all directions in the little manual. The only problem we have had is that the discharge light has come on; the booklet says that this indicates that there are about five minutes shaving time remaining. However, we have been shaving for at least 30 additional minutes (cumulatively) with no apparent reduction in shave quality. In the interest of letting the battery run down entirely before recharging (as recommended by the booklet), we have not plugged the shaver in at present. We don't know whether this will result in damage to either the shaver or the battery. We DO like that the battery appears to have a long life (corded shavers are a pain). Overall, two thumbs up -- and we hope that the longevity matches the rest of the attributes of this shaver.
  712. The razor does a good job as to its shaving ability. The only thing I do not like about it is that you have to hold the power button down while you are shaving. This makes it awkward when you change hands or switch sides of your face.
  713. After considerable research I decided to purchase this shaver over the Norelco rotories. My main goal was to obtain a shaver that would cut the hard to cut areas under my chin. My previouse Norelcos were good reliable shavers but did not handle this are well. Unfortunately, the Remington is no better. In fact, it is far more difficult to clean and still requires that I use a hand razor for the area of concern. On top of that, the Remington is a few bucks more expensive. If you want easy care and reliability, stick to the Norelco rotaries.
  714. The Remington MS3-2000 has been my favorite razor for years. I have owned 2 of these, and refitted them with new cutters and screens for years, which restores it's performance to almost like new. Unfortunately, when the batteries get old and no longer hold a decent charge, your only option is to buy a new razor since the batteries cannot be replaced. It was a crushing blow to find out the MS3-2000 was no longer manufactured. So I bought this MS2-390 because it looked (on paper) like a suitable replacement. Wrong! Cannot get the same close shave, hairs get pulled, the pop-up does not cut as well, and the red light (low charge) comes on every 3 days despite following the charging instructions exactly. It's very disappointing for a leading razor manufacturer like Remington to drop a great product and peddle this poor imitation of a quality razor. I cannot recommend it.
  715. I gave this shaver to my husband and he said it was a great shaver. Some have said the trimmer is not the best and to wide. He shaves with the trimmer out as it picks up those hard to cut whiskers. There is no pulling or scratching. He has a tough beard and it is shaved off to a smooth finish. So give it a try. Extend the trimmer and cut the shaving time needed for a close shave. The noise? What difference does it make if you get a good shave?
  716. I have not used an electric razor for some years, so it is taking some time for adjustment. However, it is working quit well.
  717. Excellent electric! Just as good as Consumer Reports rates it. I have sensitive skin, so using a classic razor is typically out of the question. I have tried a few rotary shavers (paid a pretty penny for them too), but I found that most, if not all of them, required numerous passes and a 10 minute shaving adventure to get most of the hairs. Even then, a few strays could still be found. Then, on a trip to New Orleans, I forgot my rotary and ended up buying a $10 battery operated Remington foil electric from a drugstore, and I got the best shave I had had in a long time from it. I never looked back. I had been using that for a year, but its non-replaceable blades wore down, and it was time for a new one. Amazon does sell that shaver, but I decided that a rechargeable was a better bet. This particular shaver had excellent reviews, and is rated as a CR 'Best Buy'. For the price, you can't beat that! A month later, I still love this shaver. Doesn't take many passes (one or two in general, and maybe 3 in trickier areas), and it doesn't irritate my skin at all. Its not perfect...its rare, but a stray hair or two may escape. The attached trimmer takes care of them easily though. It holds a good charge (I can get just shy of 9 days out of it) and can also be used corded. Cleaning is easy as well. I highly recommend this shaver. IMO, you can't do better, especially for the reasonable price!
  718. After a zillion years shaving my light beard with a rotary type, I thought I would try a screen shaver. I purchased the Remington MS2-390 Miroscreen model. The price is right, it is well designed and cleaning is convienient. As far as effectiveness in my case, it is certainly does the job but runs a close second to the rotery. All in all, it appears like a good choice if you are looking for a screen model.
  719. I've used Electric shavers for 32 years and FINALLY I've found one that shaves as close as a blade. The other bonus is not having to buy all the extra cleaning fluid from Braun. GREAT RAZOR and A GREAT PRICE!
  720. i think for the value, this shaver is decent. still paid around 50/60 with shipping. however, this shaver is very simple, no bells and whistles. i used the earlier model before this one and i think i liked the other one better. overall though, i think you can do worse; the battery is very good on this shaver as well
  721. I have been using it for 6 months and haven't found anything I don't like. It does what I expected it to do. I like that the battery charges in 1 hour, and will not over charge if left plugged in.
  722. Works great. I had an older Braun and was contemplating a newer one until I read the consumer reports on this one. It gave the best shave I've ever had with an electric and is the first time I could say that it challenges the closeness of a blade without the irritation.
  723. The Remington MS2-390 Microscreen 500 is a terrific value. I replaced my twice the price Norelco (it croaked) and I'm genuinely impressed with both the ease and closeness of the shave. Using this Remington is authentically a treat from my point of view :-)
  724. This razor is very loud and very slow. It takes many passes to get the same shave as my old rotary shaver. That said it does give a very nice shave, is 50 bucks less then my old shaver, and holds its charge for a long time.
  725. I had excellent service and the seller did a fantastic job.<br />The shaver is rated as #1 on Consumers Report so I tried it, even though I've always used Norelco.<br />Did a fair job but left many visual uncut beard hairs.<br />I could not get a real close shave.<br />Returned it with no problems!<br />Thanks!
  726. I have purchased and used this brand and specific product before. It gives a very close, comfortable shave. Can be used with or without cord for convenience. Short recharge time provides several lengthy shaves. Two year warranty is a plus and unusual for such a product. Also, the cost for replacement blades and foil is significantly less than similar products or rotary type shavers. Only complaint, it is somewhat noisy.
  727. Owned several Remingtons and Norelcos in the past. Often even used both during a shave because the Remington did a better job than the Norelco on certain areas. In a recent Consumers Report, this Remington was rated a best buy. Have used this exclusively for over a month and it's performed better than any previous shaver. Perhaps simplifying by just using two heads makes it better. Close, comfortable shaves. Gave my Norelco to Habitat.
  728. This Remington dual foil MS2-390 replaced my MS2-370 which was identical except that the 390 can be rinsed clean under water. Both the 370 and the 390 use the same cutter heads and micro-foils and both shave closer than a blade. I bought the 390 so I can have a nearly identical spare shaver on hand in case of an emergency. I've also used rotary style electric razors in the past, however for my beard which tends to lay at an angle in some areas, I've found the micro-screen styles like the 370/390 to shave closer and faster. An excellent product for my kind of beard.
  729. My husband LOVES this shaver. He thanks me a couple of times a week for getting it for him. He hated to shave and sometimes would go for a day or 2 without it. I was hoping this would remedy that, and it did. My dad always said that, \\"A gentleman is always clean shaven.\\" And now, my husband is too. A gentleman and clean shaven, that is. I always consult Consumer Reports and Amazon reviews before I buy anything. This was a CR Best Buy and rated the best by Amazon reviews. It has lived up to its reputation.
  730. A major evaluation source named the Remington MS2-390 as best of the low cost electric shavers. It is generally believed and I agree that electrics do an ok job of shaving but not as good as blade razors. But electrics are quick, simple, and easy. If that is your need and cost matters, you will probably be happy with the Remington MS2-390.

I had to give the razor 1 star as the page would not let me leave it blank, if I could I would give it negative stars! Would I recommend this item? Never.

  738. This razor doesn't shave closely and leaves hair/stubble, even though it was highly rated by Consumer Reports. It throws hair all down the front of the user's shirt, and also caused several facial cuts.
  739. Bought this two months ago, and am quite happy with it. I have not been an electric razor user in the past; I found that they gave a shave of inconsistent closeness. I also tend to have issues with ingrown hairs. As a result, I have been using a beard trimmer for the past couple years. However, these don't give a very close shave. This shaver is nearly optimal. The microscreen gives a very close shave, and is well shaped for getting every nook and cranny. (One exception being right under the nose. I sometimes get razor-burn if I use the screen there. In order to get a consistently close shave, especially if I let my beard grow out for a long weekend, I have to use the trimmer. This is ostensibly for lining sideburns, but I use it to shorten my whiskers before using the microscreen. Battery life is great, so far. I clean it using the included brush after almost every use, which just takes a minute. Should you purchase this shaver, I recommend keeping the microscreen's protective cover. The microscreens are delicate, so treat them with care!
  740. Product does provide a close shave, but requires the use of its built-in pop-up clipper to handle longer whiskers (A problem if you skip a day shaving, perhaps) Noisy. Long battery life.
  741. I have used this razor for a month now, and finally went back to a rotary razor to get a good shave. I followed the directions on how to use the new razor, and all I got out of it was a nice facial massage. The razor seemed like it did not have any cutting blades in it. I pulled my skin tight and the razor just rode over facial hair like it was not there. To put it simply, the razor does not cut my beard. The razor is a sad disappointment.   744. I generally shave with a double-edged razor and only use an electric for a change of pace or a touch-up. My beard is quite heavy and an electric shaver usually doesn't cut closely enough. But I think I was pressing down too hard, which isn't necessary. The only reason it doesn't rate five stars is because it's very noisy but maybe I'm just accustomed to shaving in silence. I'll probably continue to use the Remington just occasionally, but I'm glad I bought it and recommend the MS2-390 to others who prefer an electric shaver.

  756. I have use remingtion for as long as I can remember, I am 72 and have been shaving ever since I was 16. When it came time to replace my older remington I was going to try something different but after reading a lot of reviews and comparing plrices I decided on the MS-390.   757. As a retired University health researcher, I tend to over inspect everything and am taking a moment to comment on the shaver's performance. I purchased a Remington Foil Shaver MS2 390 about a year ago and I'm very pleased with my purchase and feel the price to performance ratio is high. For the last ten years I used two shavers (a three-head rotary and a blade shaver) and alternated their use because neither was totally acceptable. This Remington handle is composed of non-slip leather-like material, orthopedically shaped that fits comfortably in the hand and allows tilting for hard to reach facial areas. The double blades are very sharp and the shave head is a fine mesh gauge which provides very close and quick beard removal - shave time requires ~half the time of my old shavers. A side-burn cutter pops up and trims quite well. Once a month I use the cutter to clip hairs on my neck. The screen housing removes easily and the cleaning brush allows clipping to be removed, followed by a quick puff or air to remove the fine hair clippings. Use the brush lightly - when the shaver was new, I accidentally knocked a blade out of its clamp with too vigorous brushing - blades are easily re-attached. The battery holds a strong charge which lasts ~14 days - a red light glows when the battery is low. A sturdy leather case protects the shaver when I travel. After a years use the shave screen develop a small hole - I purchase a replacement screen (Replacement Part SP-69) and new blades at Wall-Mart for $21.00 + tax (on Web: [...] for $16.99 + shipping????). Replacing the delicately fine screen was a little tricky - when I did take a moment to read and follow the enclosed instructions, replacement was quick and simple. Thoroughly satisfied. JW 11-11-11
  758. This is the 3rd Remington Model MS2-390 Shaver I've used and I really like the closeness you get when shaving.
  759. The foil did not last a week ! Ordered another foil and again the foil cracked and became unusable ! I bought for price but got burned by awful product. I feel Remington should reach out to me and refund or replace this poorly designed made foil razor with a more durable one! Live and learn!
  760. To be honest, I only bought this shaver for the pop-up trimmer. I dont like a close shave, and I've been shaving my face and neck with trimmers for years. This trimmer is pretty weak and inefficient compared to other shavers I've used. It's just not powerful and doesnt cut the hairs well. Eventually I get a good shave, but it takes a long time of going over my face over and over. I think I'm going to buy a different shaver and just keep this as a backup. The previous Remington model that I had, Remington F4790, is cheaper than this one and does a better job (at least as far as the trimmer goes). There is also a thin dark blue coating on the blue rubber grip that keeps flaking off, so I have to look in the mirror after shaving each morning to make sure I don't have a blue flake or two on my shirt or face. Unfortunately, all these things happened after the warranty ran out, so now I have a 2 year old shaver that looks like it is 10 years old. It's not clear how much longer it will work.

  797. I just bought this again to replace an older one of the same model that I bought about 2 years ago. My old one was starting to lose battery capacity and the whisker trimmer was not working well anymore. I only had to change the screens twice in two years. The screens are the worst part about this and any razor because they are either expensive or they are crappy knockoff brands, or they charge you lots to ship those little babies.<br /><br />For me, the whisker trimmer is important and this one is decent for getting longer hairs and neck hairs. It occasionally catches on a hair, but it otherwise does the job. The screen shave is close and good. The batteries on the new unit last forever--well, weeks anyway. The screen holder is a little flimsy. It clips in place, but just barely. If you bump it, sometimes it pops off. This was a problem in my old razor, too, but not too bad to cause problems. All in all, it's a decent razor for the price, although I remember it being even cheaper a couple years ago.

  807. I got lazy and went back to the razor, but when I did use it, it worked fantastic! I think it feels cheap though and when I cleaned the blades, one of them kept popping out too easily. I think it cuts better than the Panasonic I used to own.

  809. I have used this Remington mode lhappily for several years and ordered another for my New York part-time residence. When it arrivedI the trimmer would not stay retracted so I returned it for a replacement. When the replacement arrived it had the same problem. I returned it and bought a Norelco AT810 which I have been happy with now for about two weeks.
  810. I bought it for a neighbor.
  811. I bought this to replace an expensive BRAUN shaver that I have been using for the last ten years. I have replaced the foil shaving head and blade at least ten times over the years. One day, I was at my lady friend's house, and I had forgotten to pack my BRAUN shaver. My Lady suggested I use the battery powered Remington that she bought to shave her legs. This was a cheap thing, battery powered and not a rechargeable. I shaved with it, and the shave was closer, smoother, quicker then I ever got with the old BRAUN. I guess the technology has improved in the last decade. I then went on Amazon, and looked for Remington rechargeable shavers. I narrowed it down to this model, based on the customer reviews. I have been using it for about a month, and it has far exceeded all my expectations. There are a few tricks that I had to learn, that pretty much eliminate the complaints from the reviews that were critical.<br />Number one: DO not press hard on the shaver (like I was used to with the BRAUN. You will irritate the skin of your face.<br />Number Two: Do not shave dry. That is.... shower first before you shave.<br />Number three: A couple of drops of Pre-Electric shave lotion goes a long way to help this awesome tool do it's job.<br />Number 4: Use a very light touch when shaving. The way this tool efficiently removes the hardest of whisker hair will astound you.<br />In summary, I've never gotten a closer shave with less effort, than I have with this Remington. I highly recommend this product. P.S. I bought an extra foil and cutter, so I never have to go a single day without my awesome Remington.
  812. I guess I have a somewhat unique view on this thing since I'm writing this long after I bought it and have stopped using it.<br />Basically it's a pain. I'll never buy another micro screen. The blades were expensive and didn't last very well at all despite my best attempts at their care.<br /><br />I tried using their fancy powder stick stuff they recommend also. Barely made any difference.<br /><br />Battery in the thing finally started going south after about a year of mostly annoying use. Buh-bye<br /><br />Using quality disposable razors now. Get my face shaved in a third of the time compared to any electric.
  813. This product is OK. I would not buy another one.The job it does is so so. I find it irritates my skin and is unable to do much with the beard under my chin.
  814. Last Remington razor I owned, I used for at least 9 years. I replaced the screen and foil a couple of times but the battery and razor went on and on until the button fell off! Glad to get a replacement....shaving is fun again!
  815. The battery on the Remington MS2-390 I purchased 10 years ago quit taking a charge and the switch cover was worn out...so I bought a whole new shaver. It is identical in design but the price increased $35. I noticed that the cutting speed is greater, so shaving time is reduced. The battery may have been improved because it doesn't slow as much as the charge diminishes. This Remington fits the contours of my face much better than rotary-style shavers and the built-in trimmer is very handy. The only drawback is that the cutting blades only last about 6 months and replacements are a bit pricey. As with so many other 'American' products...it is now made in China; however, the quality still remains high.
  816. Does not shave as close as expected. Noisy. Trimmer not as good as those on other shavers. Would not recommend.
  817. I have a heavy beard and no electric shaver gives me the shave of a good blade, but I have found that this type of foil-head shaver works for me for &#34;knockin' the top off&#34; and doing it with relative comfort. The weak link in this model, as was the one it replaced, is the trimmer pop up mechanism...the soft plastic parts that latch the trimmer in the down position will wear out and the trimmer will not stay down after several years of use. I actually forceably ripped out the trimmer on my previous Remington (three years old) when it would not retract and stay retracted. The soft touch plastic coating where you grip the shaver also &#34;go away&#34; relatively quickly though this doesn't affect the functionality of the razor. Also it is altogether too easy to accidently press one of the screen release buttons when you are shaving, which can' t be good for the blades and screen when the shaver is running. Replacement blades and screens, when you can find them, are also quite expensive. Needless to say, I view this unit as a back up to a blade, such as when travelling.
  818. I bought this for my husband who always liked his previous razor. It works well, gives him a close shave, but it is louder than his previous shaver.
  819. I have now used the razor for about 3 weeks and am very satisfied with it. I bought a Braun first, and stopped using it after about two weeks, because of poor workmanship and poor shaves. I then ordered this razor and wish I had gotten it to begin with. I think this is probably the best razor I have owned in over 55 years of shaving (I am 72 years old).

  836. This is a poor, inconsistent shaver. I spend more time shaving with this than a disposable razor and still end up with patches of unshaven hair, especially under my chin. I could go over these patches a dozen times in different angles and levels of pressure, and still not get all of the hair. The length of my hair doesn't seem to matter. If it has been 2 days or 5 days since my last shave, this thing is still just as bad at cutting it. The extendible trimmer only helps a little bit; not worth discussing.<br /><br />There is mention of waiting 3 weeks without using a different shaving method to get the best shave, though it never actually explains what this means. I believe it just means it will _feel_ better after 3 weeks, but I don't care... it feels fine now; it just can't cut my hair. Even if it were the case that it would shave better after these 3 weeks, what am I supposed to do until then, walk around with a half-shaven beard?<br /><br />This is my first electric razor. I heard they weren't as close of a shave as disposable razors, but I thought that would be a fair trade for the obscene cost of disposable razors. I've used this product a total of 3 separate times, and am disappointed. If this, a Consumer Reports top pick, is any indication of how electric razors typically perform, then my journey with them is done. I'm going to test the waters of double-edge safety razors instead...
  837. Delivers a very good shave and at a reasonable price. This is a Consumer Reports recommended item,and I am glad I purchased it.
  838. I needed to replace a Braun that had worn-out batteries and chose the Remington MS2-390 based on reviews in a \\"leading consumer magazine\\" and user comments posted here at Amazon. Plus, the MS2-390 can be rinsed in water. Overall the Remington MS2-390 is a very good razor for the money.

This razor doesn't do a very good job on head hair stubble, it's much better with thick, coarse facial hair than the finer hair on your head.<br />Also, the model is noisier than other models I've had, but I don't know if it's an aspect of the microscreen design.   869. WOW! Awesome shave! After a very frustrating few months with a POS Braun 30-series, I finally Goodwill-ed the thing and went back to Remington. *FABULOUS PRODUCT*. And I might not be crazy about the trimmer (I'd give it four-and-a-half stars because of the trimmer). But overall, this might be the best shaver I have ever used (40yrs of shaving electric). WARNING: this product could be used to sand off your face... and that as it should be. I love this thing, almost makes me giddy using it.<br /><br />** update one year later **<br /><br />While still the best shave I've ever had, I find myself increasingly frustrated with the lifespan of the thing. After 11 months, it's very close to needing replacement. The rubber cover over the switch deteriorated to the point where I had to tear it off, and the blades barely hang on to where they clip in (they fall off at every cleaning, soon they won't stay on when the thing is running). I guess I'm going to purchase another one in preparation for my existing unit failing altogether... but I'd have hoped for a product that would last more than a year?
  870. I was disappointed by my recent purchase of the MS2-390 Microscreen Rechargeable/Corded Men's Shaver. Within 3 weeks the pop-up whisker shaver spring was broken where I must tape it down with duct tape in order to continue shaving with it until I can contact Remington's customer service. I bought it to replace the same shaver because after 3 years, the battery does not recharge for long and I cannot just plug the previous shaver into the socket as advertised and use it on AC. In addition, the previous Remington rubberized 'on' button had deteriorated. If I do not get quick satisfaction, I will go back to Norelco.
  871. This venerable 5 year old model seems to be still going strong as it is currently #14 on Amazon's Best Seller list for foil shavers. That is probably because it is good value for the money.<br />For me, this shaver has two strong points and several weak ones. The main strong point is that it shaves really close for an electric shaver at ANY price point, let alone $58. In fact, it gives my high-end Braun Series7 and Panasonic ES-LA63 a run for their money. And what can be more important than closeness? Second, it retains the cut whiskers really well so you don't mess up your shirt or chest.<br />Now for the cons. The noise from the motor is ridiculously loud, much louder than any other shaver I've tried. The wide curved body is too broad for my smallish hands and feels clumsy and difficult to maneuver, especially on the neck and jawline. The trimmer only has 2 positions, not 3 as advertised, unless you consider closed a position. It is located on the front just below the foils and runs the full length of the head. In the first position it rises ever so slowly to be flush with the foils and to act as a third blade, presumably to take down longer hairs that grow beside the shorter ones. But whose face has long and short hairs at the same time? Surely not mine. In the second position it rises slowly again to about 1/4 inch above the foils to act as a sideburn trimmer and the like. The problem here is it doesn't rise high enough to be of much use. The trimmer opens by pressing a button but only closes by pressing down with your thumb. In the closed position it will rub against your face, which is uncomfortable, if you are not holding the razor at right angles to your face as you should be.<br />So there you have my take on the MS2-390. If closeness is of utmost importance to you, this is an inexpensive good value providing a close shave without much irritation. As such, I would give it 3.5 stars if I could.
  872. This is about the fourth one of this model i have owned....they work very well and gives me a pretty clean shave
  873. Works fantastic but head keeps popping off making a mess will not purchase this line again. Very poor fastening design
  874. this Remington is a lot quicker than the modern remingtons that are crap. this one is the older model and much more superior in every way than the new models which I have tossed in the garbage can. Y ou wont find this model in strores for some reasonand I think I know why.
  875. Over what they are selling now.<br />The two main issues are noise and the inability to easily change the two AA NiMh cells. The problem with their less expensive models is no ability to charge the cells and shave at the same time. The manufacturing cost has to be very little. It's just more profit for everyone involved.<br /><br />Screens & cutters are inexpensive (if you know where to look). I found a package of two cutters & two screens for $9.. I have also seen the same thing go for $25. Like printers, I always look at the cost of consumables since that will be the major expense over the products lifetime.
  876. I bought myself this unit in about 2007 or 08 after having a Remington micro screen since I think 1989. On the old one, I'd replaced and serviced a very few things over the years, mostly just screens, blades, the head a couple times maybe then part of the case broke. I'd had it almost 20 yrs.<br /><br />Thinking, they'd been good to me, I'll stick with them. The new one: First it hurt my face and one of the blades kept falling out every time I'd remove the head to clean it. CS sent new blades and for some reason the hurt stopped, but the same blade kept falling out.<br />My son soon began to shave so i got him the same model. Coincidentally, almost immediately the rubber over my power button began to come off on mine. Then, once using his, I noticed his was considerably more comfortable. What an insult, I dealt with that irritation all that time- I'd used mine a couple yrs before this discovery. And now I'm discovering it had some kind of defect all along , and the warrantee was probably up.<br />Eventually I changed to a Phillips Norellco (sp?), but have since discovered my son says his button rubber came completely off some time ago and on his, now BOTH the blades fall out every time he cleans it, and he has to hold them (we clean after every use and it stays sharp much longer). It's also quite noisy compared to the Norelco rotary one , a concern when shaving while trying to let ones' wife or partner sleep.<br /><br />Shame on a once great american product to sully their name just to increase their profit. Who gains? Oh yeah, one guy or a small handful of already rich guys. Meanwhile, how many hard working american workers who'd made exceptional products are displaced, and the rest of us get a product that's actually useless in the end, I had to stop using mine! They should get what they deserve: to go out of business (I spent $72 bucks for something that sits under the bathroom sink), or loose market share until they re-establish quality in theirproduct.

  912. ... which they stopped making 3 years ago... then you'll LOVE this one. I liked the early Remington cutters because they had a motor that would last 12 or more years. Then came the ES-1000 cutter (that was shaped like the MS2-390), but the motor (or battery) conked after just 2 years. I didn't care how close they shaved... I just wanted to shave every 3 or 4 days.<br />The ES-1000 was a no cord shaver, so that must have been why it didn't last long. Anyways, I bought the MS-390 after giving up on my Braun single head (took way too long to shave) and I must say... this one is BETTER than the ES-1000 and does the same job QUICKLY with a much closer shave. This way I can wait a little longer between shaves. And I could care less if the noise was louder than a lawn mower as long as it did the job. It does (so far). I've had it for only 3 months now so HOPEFULLY it will last much longer than 2 years. If it doesn't, then I give up on Remington.
  913. This didn't shave very well and I ended up just throwing it away. Definitely not worth the money I spent for it
  914. I really like the way my Remington shaver works but the battery doesn't charge for long.
  915. My husband had an older version of this one. He tried a totally different brand of razor after his old Remington died. He didn't like the new Philips Norelco one bit. I was then put on the path to finding a new razor like his old one (which was discontinued a long time ago). I found this on the wonderful Amazon website and it's the newer version to the one he previously had. He likes it just fine. There are a few things that he would like to change, but I seriously think it's because he would like to have had his old razor back. He's not a fan of the electronic movement of the trimmer. All in all, pleasing a man who's set in his ways, he really likes this one!
  916. This was a replacement for one almost identical. I had used it for perhaps seven years daily and it began to wear out. The new one has been improved to hold the cutters better and the battery life seems longer, too. The best I have had over many years shaving.with electric razors.
  917. I think I bought this about three years ago. I have a really thick beard, and it cuts it, but I do have to go over it a few times to really get it. The shave could probably be a little closer, but it works.

  924. MS2-390 Shaver Review.<br /> First the good point This shaver shaves great and the motor runs about twice as fast as my old Remington MS-2 290 The older model ran on 4.5 Volts The MS2-390 runs on 12 Volts and it very warm to the touch after charging which means it is drawing twice as many watts from the wall! Even though it works great I am sending it back tonight because it is so noisey! ! ! It measured 96 DB on my noise meater with the mike one inch from the razor. Puting in earplugs is a real paine! I see there are still some of the MS-2 290 out there. Even though it will cost me about $10 more for the older model it is still a good deal. I got five years of good consteant use out of my old MS-2 290 I will bet the new MS2-390 motor will soon burn out. You will be lucky if you get past the 90 day worenty. Ed
  925. I have been using this Shaver for a while now. No problems so far. Shaves close for an electric. Microscreens wear out a little too soon for me.
  926. Decent for the price. It will start to tear down after a while. Button and pop out trimmer all broke after a couple of years. Foils don't last as long as previous models. They tear within a couple of months.
  927. the worst electric shaver I have ever used. I want my money back! only thing that works is the trimmer that pops up.
  928. Thanks to Remington products now available at their website, I have replaced my old shaver with the brand I prefer.
  929. Bought for my 16 yr old son. I didn't want to spend a lot since he had been shaving with a regular razor and I wasn't sure he would like an electric, but this one is lightweight, sturdy, easy to take care of, and easy enough to clean. It's fairly compact and I think was a good deal for the price.

  932. I have had several different razors, but the Remington MS2-390 is the best razor for the money. This razor has been around for awhile and this is my third MS2-390. The battery won't last forever, but it can be used with the cord if the battery goes dead.
  933. My husband has to use an electric razor and this is the best he has found so far. Let us know when you make a better one and he will buy it. Until then, he will be happy with this one.
